reviewText:
I foolishly questioned this spy thriller film. Now I know I was a fool and the film is a triumph, in the spirit of greatness that follows men like Spielberg, Hanks, Alda, and Rylance. They create film worlds from drive, not just for the need of a noon meal. They choose roles/films, and in Bridge of Spies they selectedc well, and performed at their peak.

I was nostalgically blown away; away back to 1957 (I was age 9). I was there doing the school air raid drills of duck & cover, Elvis Rock 'n Roll, hearing of Sputnik, U2 shot down, American Bandstand, the perfect Chevy design, the Berlin wall being built brick by brick with barbed wire and blood, B&W TV, living in a family of 7 and Mom wore Pop-it Beads.
I was wrong to expect the normal spy-thriller stunt-action filled drivel. This film looks as people, lifestyle, events, and the subdued real-history ambiance of the late 1950s Cold War, Americans Boomer Norman Rockwell families, and ideas and secrets being the wars front line. Spielberg caught the era perfectly. Tom Hanks takes viewers to a flag-waving feel-good-about-America ending.
I was as mesmerized in Bridge of Spies period cinematography as happened with Spielbergs War Horse, Saving Private Ryan, Schindlers List, & Lincoln.

Insurance lawyer Donovan (Hanks) gets the official nod to defend a KGB officer/spy (Mark Rylance The Other Boleyn Girl) whos to be traded for downed U2 pilot Powers (Austin Stowell). Donovans wife (Amy Ryan) is perfection as the typical 1950s mom/housewife in action, word, and wardrobe. She made me feel like I was looking through my own family photo scrapbooks. Dont forget Alan Aldas (M*A*S*H) always perfect performances, as 50s honest as the Korean War.

One to view big in the cinema followed by ordering the DVD or stream.
What a fool I was to expect less. This is good for film intellectuals.
Spielberg has achieved Stratosphere status since ET went home.

Please read no further, if you are concerned about spoilers....

The refreshingly wholesome theme of this movie seems to simply be the importance of doing the right thing.  Tom Hanks' James Donovan is an "everyman" placed on center stage by the unfolding of history.

Once again our favorite Everyman Tom Hanks is working with his long- time friend and collaborator Steven Spielberg ("Saving Private Ryan" and "Band of Brothers"). These guys seem convinced that Americans need to know more WWII history. Lucky for us the Coen brothers are on the writing team, they bring some very dry humor to the Cold War as we watch two superpowers (plus East Germany) negotiate an exchange of spies.

This time Hanks is an insurance lawyer ordered to defend a Russian spy. His reluctance to side with the enemy is justified when his family is targeted by outraged citizens who now see him as anti-American. We also watch as some Air Force pilots are assigned to the CIA; they will fly camera-equipped U2 spy planes 70,000 feet above the USSR. They are called "drivers" and are instructed to commit suicide if they are caught. They are stunned!

We see:
  * Tom Hanks ("The Terminal") is perfect as James Donovan, a highly rated attorney who hasn't practiced criminal law in decades. He's smart, funny, and very, very resourceful. He quickly realizes his "client" will be denied Constitutional protection by the American courts. As a lawyer responsible for an accused prisoner, all he can do now is try to prevent the death penalty.
  * Amy Ryan ("Birdman:...") is Mary, his wife. When he goes to East Berlin to negotiate a trade - his Russian spy for the American pilot of a downed spy plane - she thinks he's going to Scotland to fish.
  * Alan Alda ("The Longest Ride") is Thomas Watters, Donovan's boss. It's at his insistence that Donovan must take up this case.
  * Austin Stowell ("Behind the Candelabra") is Francis Gary Powers, a U2 pilot (not the band!) who was shot down from Russian skies.
  * Mark Rylance ("Wolf Hall") is amazing as Rudolf Abel, the notorious agent who meticulously eludes discovery for so long. When asked if he is frightened, he replies, "Would it help?"
  * Sebastian Koch ("The Lives of Others") Wolfgang Vogel is the East German official who resents being overlooked by the two superpowers who ignore him...in his own city!
  * Will Rogers ("The Bay") is Frederic Pryor, a student caught behind the Berlin wall as he tries to rescue his girlfriend. Donovan wants him to be part of the deal, too.

The Cold War, Donovan, Abel, Powers... Many of these names will draw a blank from the younger generation because History as a school subject is no longer considered politically correct. Do they know about the Berlin Wall? We see it being built in this wonderful film; AND for period touches, we see an astonishing array of vintage cars, plus discarded flash bulbs on the floor. In addition, Donovan makes a terrific speech to the Supreme Court about what makes America unique.

I can't help but recall George Santanaya's immortal quote: "Those who do not remember the past are condemned to repeat it." More's the pity... Every young American should see this PG-13 movie. (By the way, be sure to stay for the terrific postscripts!)

"Bridge of Spies" (2015 release; 141 min.)  brings the story of how insurance lawyer Jim Donovan became involved in negotiating a prisoner exchange in Berlin between the US and the USSR. As the movie opens, we are told that it is "1957, the height of the cold war". We then follow someone in Brooklyn, who after a long chase sequence gets arrested for spying for the Russians. In order to make it look like the spy is getting due process and a "fair shake", the US government appoints a lawyer to represent him. Turns out to be NY insurance lawyer (and ex-Nurnberg assistant prosecutor) Jim Donovan. To tell you more would spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: this is the latest in series of historical "inspired by true events" movies from director Steven Spielberg, this time directing from a script by Matt Charman, Ethan Coen and Joel Coen (yes, THE Coen brothers). I had seen the trailer a number of times, and was expecting a riveting movie in line with earlier historical movies from Spielberg such as Saving Private Ryan, Schindler's List, and Munich. Alas, it was not to be. The movie lacks any tension whatsoever, and has the feeling of having been done strictly "by the numbers". The best scenes are when we get to Berlin, in the frantic days as the wall was being completed and people were desperate to get out of East Berlin. And the of course the climax of the movie, filmed on the real bridge of spies (the Glienicke Bridge in Berlin, near Potsdam--I had the good fortune of visiting this site a few years ago, it gave me the chills walking on it). There are several noteworthy acting performances: Tom Hanks (in his 4th cooperation with Spielberg) as Jim Donovan, and  Mark Rylance as the spy Rudolf Abel (great line: Donovan: "you're not worried?", to which Abel responds: "would it help?", ha!). As always with Spielberg, the production is terrific and authentic in to the smallest of details. Last but certainly not least: the orchestral score is, shockingly, NOT by John Williams, which I believe marks the first time in 40 years in a Steven Spielberg (the score is from Thomas Newman, who does a fine job). Bottom lime: I found "Bridge of Spies" strangely subdued and to me it feels like Spielberg played it safe in this one.

"Bridge of Spies" opened nationwide this weekend, and I couldn't wait to see it. The early evening screening where I saw this at here in Cincinnati was attended okay, but frankly I had expected a lot more people, given this is the movie's opening weekend. I have seen most of Spielberg's movies and must admit this to me feels like one of the weaker movies he's done in a long time. Is it bad? Of course not, but neither is it great. Nevertheless, this is of course a personal and subjective view, and I would encourage you to check out "Bridge of Spies", be it in the theater, on Amazon Instant Video or eventually on DVD/Blu-ray, and draw your own conclusions.

It is 1957.  The Cold War is well underway.  The United States and the Soviet Union, each fearing the other's nuclear arsenal, are engaged in an intense espionage duel.  "Bridge of Spies" opens with the arrest of Rudolf Abel, Soviet spy, in Brooklyn, New York.  Insurance lawyer James Donovan is asked to provide his defense at trial, a thankless task that Donovan nevertheless undertakes with more than due diligence.  Meanwhile, the CIA is recruiting pilots for its highly secret U-2 program.  One of the recruits is Air Force1LT Francis Gary Powers.  Powers will be shot down over the Soviet Union in 1960 and convicted of espionage by a Soviet court.

Donovan will be asked by the CIA to arrange an exchange of Powers for Abel.  Donovan travels to Berlin, arriving just as East Germany is putting up its infamous wall, trapping its own citizenry and at least one unfortunate American student on the wrong side.  Donovan will shuttle back and forth between East and West, navigating several bureaucracies and multiple political fault lines to try to negotiate an exchange. In the end, the story, and the suspense, comes down to a darkened bridge between the two Berlins and the question of who will be exchanged...

Director Steven Spielberg has done a masterful job presenting this movie, which is authentic to the period and nuanced in its delivery.  He doesn't hide the U.S. government's hardball pursuit of Abel, but plainly portrays the brutality of the East German government.  Tom Hanks as Donovan steals the show as a principled man walking a narrow line in a high stakes competition.  Mark Rylance manages to make the spy Abel a sympathetic figure.  Scott Shepherd is watchable as Donovan's CIA contact and foil.  There is an excellent supporting cast, including Amy Ryan as Donovan's wife and a cameo by Alan Alda as Donovan's boss.  Highly recommended, especially to those who lived the Cold War.

Steven Spielberg directs one of his finest films with this relevant espionage historical drama. The idea that all people deserve rights and legal representation is more relevant than ever before. The direction is immaculately crafted with beautiful long panning shots and careful visual storytelling. We witness U.S., Russian, and German diplomacy during the Cold War. It's a very interesting prisoner negotiation movie.

The Coen Brothers wrote a very thoughtful and fair script that depicts all countries honestly, while also entertaining the audience with jokes and knowledge. Strong writing and dialogue leads Bridge of Spies to excellence.

Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance lead the charge with their complex portrayals of historical figures Donovan and Abel. Hanks plays it straight with some humor to humanize his lawyer. He captures Donovan's dedication to the law, justice, and decency. Meanwhile, Rylance plays Abel with a cold poker face and a knowing somber tone. These are great actors at their peak skills. Bridge of Spies is all the more delightful because of their performances.

In all, Bridge of Spies is an important movie for Spielberg to recount a moment in history, while also being accessible to all audiences and enjoyable simultaneously.

Tom Hanks in the lead role and Mark Rylance as the captured Russian spy were excellent. Hanks was impeccable in his holding to human values rather than caving in to the cynicism of the other political figures in the film-the CIA agents, the American public, and the Russian and East German political figures. The Cold War was portrayed as a time of bitter acrimony and hatred directed at the wrong people for the wrong reasons. Mass psychology was pictured as a part of American life at that time. The Russian side was pictured in all its one-sided brutality and ugliness  His skillful role as a clever and subtle negotiator, Mark Rylance's dogged and matter of fact, philosophical playing of his part as the spy, the unyielding judge, the people in position of authority from the lawyers to the police and the embassy staff, all these combined to  make this a convincing, close-to-real-life picture of the relationships that are part of the political world at any time. Thumbs up to this Spielberg masterpiece! Thank you, Amazon for providing me with this film to view on my computer here at home.

A fine film. Excellent acting, well-written, and the scenes of Berlin as the wall is going up are excellent. James Donovan (Hanks) is drafted into defending Rudolf Abel, a Soviet spy, and later, is drafted into the lead role of exchanging Abel for Francis Gary Powers, an American shot down during a U-2 spying flight over the Soviet Union. In defending Abel against the death penalty, Donovan argues that if Americans are ever captured spying, we wouldn't want them executed, and it might be possible some day even to exchange such prisoners, obviously the plot of the film.

But Spielberg also has Donovan argue that Abel was loyally doing what he saw as in the interest of his country just as we're shown that Powers was doing as well. Here, Spielberg falls into moral equivalence. Abel had worked for the Soviets under Stalin, a regime that murdered millions. In the film we see the communists building the Berlin wall to keep its subjects from escaping (I was in Berlin, visited the East through Check Point Charlie in its heyday), gunning down people who try, arresting and torturing people. Donovan even talks to Abel about whether he, Abel, will be shot by his masters if he returns. Spielberg offers moral distortion by showing Abel as a quiet, introspective man who paints for a hobby and, oh yes, is somehow honorable as a spy for the regime he works for. Spielberg did not do this in "Schindler's List," though he flirted with it in "Munich" as well.

"Bridge of Spies" is a fine film but Spielberg could have avoided moral equivalence and made a more interesting film if, instead of presenting Abel as an honorable man, he had given us a glance of the darkness inside that would cause Adel, certainly not a savage brute himself, to work for the cause of savage brutes.

Excellent film. Slow pace, but that allows you to absorb all the nuances. Tom Hanks does an excellent job in this film, he really is a very good actor. He is understated and elegant, believable. All the actors are good, in fact. I remember when the Berlin wall was built, just barely, and I remember when Gary Powers was released by the USSR. I didn't know all the back story, so this film is a good history lesson as well as being a good story. I like the feeling that this is a black and white film, though in fact it is not. If you like films like "Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy," then you'll like this one as well.

P.S. I remember being taught "duck and cover" in elementary school although it never made me feel confident. And, of course, if an actual hydrogen bomb went off anywhere near the school, we would all be toast no matter how well we ducked.

Tom Hanks' performance was stellar as it always is. Cinematography was great and the story kept me interested the entire time. The movie stands out as one of the few that is not the cookie cutter crap that Hollywood has been spewing out these past few years.

So much to love about this movie: Rylance/Hanks pairing of exquisitely balanced temperaments and the sets which include German Democratic Republic messengers bicycling through embassy hallways, wooden and chrome interior of the public train, and horrors of wintry Eastern Germany with gangs, wild dogs and citizens beings shot like dogs for attempting to cross over the newly erected Berlin Wall. This is in contrast to swell, sunny Fifties Cold War Brooklyn -- you know, back when everybody was white and the Russians were scheming? All of the groups of white men in various office settings, agendas flying, characters unfolding.
We witness Hanks and Rylance act according to principles without expectation of decency in return. Hanks, an impassioned defender of the Constitution, gets nothing but grief from his wife (the unrelentingly excellent Amy Ryan), his boss, the CIA and an assortment of wack diplomats. A man true to his word he stays solid and grounded in the face of drama, preening and pretense. Getting neither respect, acknowledgement, nor support he persists in a string of melodramatic exchanges as exactly who and what he is: the reliable insurance guy who acts and communicates clearly, consistently, firmly and calmly.
Rylance embodies a drier, more detached persona. His character understands all and expects nothing. When confronted with his lawyer's honorable practices he communicates the perfect parable to illustrate simultaneously his true appreciation in tandem with his awareness that much is outside of either of their control. He utters such truisms as "I'm not afraid to die, Mr. Donovan, although it is not my first choice."
This brings me to the screenplay which was written by - - - the Coen brothers! and some other guy.
Props to Scott Shepherd, the dickless Agency guyunburdened by subtlety or empathy, the perfect foil, or fool, to Hanks' Donovan who will not suffer him gladly.
As with Lincoln, and Schindler, Spielberg is depicting another ubermensch who keeps his head as the surrounding crowd morphs into a mob. There are so many elegant details, including a nickel extracted from a spy cache that neatly separates for the transmission of coded messages. Spielberg's cinematographer embraces extremes of climate from slick black umbrellas in the darkest, densest downpour to copious flurries among bombed out buildings, soldiers, guns and gangs.
And in the midst of all the hullaballoo two smart, solid, stolid characters acknowledging their shared qualities across a binary cultural divide.

Why does nobody care that this is such a globalist/progressive re-write of history. So typical of Hollywood to make a liberal sermon instead of just tell the truth. There is total moral equivalence made here between post 1950's Russia that killed 40 million of its own citizens and the US. Americans are portrayed as bigoted morons while the Russian is like Jesus. The real nuclear threat of the USSR is completely minimized, while the hero is a liberal judicial activist. There were a few gaffes in the movie, which I noticed, including showing a brief scene of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. which wasn't in existence, when this movie was supposed to have taken place. Also, the scene on the New York City subway showed the hard plexiglass seats, which do not contain cushions. In the 1950's, all of the New York City subway seats were cushioned.

Bridge of Spies is a dad movie. In fact, it is one of the most dad movies I have ever seen. It is pleasant and predictable and slightly overlong with an upbeat feel good ending that brings a sniffle and tear to dad's eye. Honestly, I have to go back to The Right Stuff to find a more dad movie.

Tom Hanks plays Tom Hanks as if Tom Hanks found himself in To Kill a Mockingbird all of a sudden. So much so one fully expected his younger daughter to be named Scout. In all fairness, he mixes this in with a segue into Mr. Smith goes to Washington and a touch of Walter Mitty. In other words, he has gone full all American Dad. All that said he is actually quite good in the role. Like he is wearing a comfortable pair of shoes.

The movie is well cast. Every shot is well composed with the experienced eye of Spielberg. It is an incredibly handsome movie even if it sometimes comes across as a little safe.

There is one scene in particular with Toms daughter Scout watching television and a said to my wife someone is going to throw a brick through the window. There was no reason for the scene set-up and shot except for the brick through the window trope. (Which in all fairness actually happened in real life except neither Hanks character nor his family were home at the time)

Interestingly the movie was actually attempted to be filmed before with Gregory Peck in 1965 but was considered too sensitive due to Cold War tensions. This was the perfect Gregory Peck role.

Spielberg got a tear in my eye at the end and the film was more entertaining than it had any right to be. If you have a dad in your life spend a nice Sunday afternoon watching this film with him. You won't regret it.

Very good historic drama with fine performances from almost everyone. I have some quibbles with the movie. Gary Francis Power is barely portrayed in the movie, the shooting down of the U2 was not well done, and was some unnecessary errors in the period details. Subway passengers are reading the never existing New York Register but in another shot someone is reading the New York Post. Instead of the Register, there were the NY Daily Mirror, The Herald Tribune, or The NY World-Telegram and Sun that were newspapers of that era.

Nitpicking aside, I highly recommend the movie. 4.5 stars out of 5.

Tom Hanks stars as an American lawyer that was assigned a task no American wanted at the time...His character was inexplicably brought to life by Hanks performance...You will find yourself fully immersed into the story that was so vividly brought to life by Hanks and Spielberg...The story, however embellished, gives the Americans at least some sense of how the story most likely played out, of course, us being the "good" and the "evil" being the East Germans and the Russians...But any intellectual can clearly see through any fictional embellishments and understand the story being conveyed....And it is a heart warming, fairy tail ending fantastic story, that EVERY American should be required to sit down and learn, whether by this short movie, or by the literature easily found by searching the web...I give this film 5 stars easily, if only because it sits completely alone....I have seen no other movie in recent history that even requires any more than a fifth grade literacy, and this film finally at least raises the bar a bit higher, and for that, as an avid viewer of all things streaming, I am thankful....You will ABSOLUTELY want to devote a couple of hours, and a bag of fully salted, and buttered popcorn to this movie, and take my word, it will be well worth it...

I'll give it 5 starts for being exceedingly excellent on all levels of directing, cinematography, writing, and production/set design. Spielberg is certainly one of the few directors who understand the craft of film-making backwards and forwards start to finish.

Spielberg and Coen brothers fans should be warned, however, that both director and script favor understatement in their story-telling. The most exciting moment is a 5-10 minute sequence when Gary Powers and his U-2 get shot down over Russia. The rest of the movie deals with Hanks and many other decent individuals trying to do the right thing in a maze of international relations and misinformed public opinion. Because this is a Spielberg movie, you can be sure that hard work and common decency are rewarded--tho' Spielberg and his writers are careful to show in the movie's last 30 minutes that problems of evil and corruption still threaten our beloved American way of life.

All praise aside, I don't buy the idea that many spies in the Cold War were average guys drafted under false pretenses and then hung out to dry by their deceptive cold-hearted sponsor countries. I think there was some truth to the cloak-and-dagger clichs. The CIA, for example, was actively involved in numerous assassination and coup attempts. These covert operatives were not just a bunch of swell guys who were just trying to help out their country.

I also wondered--I ask for everyone's pardon here--how Spielberg's and the Coens' attitude toward their material would have been different if they had made a movie about anti-Jewish Nazi spies before the end of WWII. My guess is that their attitude toward the spy game would have been more negative and critical. But this opinion is just a surmising on my part.

Even though the movie's view of Cold War politics might be inaccurate and overly forgiving, it's an excellent piece of entertainment. You can't go wrong with it.

P.S. The movie uses the Cuban missile crisis to great dramatic effect, but most historians these days will tell you that the importance of the whole thing was greatly exaggerated. No doubt many Americans felt terrified, but, whether you launch the missiles from Cuba, Eastern Europe, or some submarine off the New England coast, the nuclear threat would have been same.

This movie smoked. I mean it was really really good. I was not sure what to expect, but it was definitely 5 star. Tom Hanks was excellent as he always is. The fact that is based on a true story makes it even better.

Rudolf Abel, a Russian spy is caught in NY. Everyone believes he is guilty. James Donovan, portrayed by Tom Hanks, is defending him. Jim is being followed by the CIA, they want to make sure that he does the right thing, lose the case. Evidence was gathered without a search warrant and Jim requests that the evidence not be allowed during the trial.  The court denies the blocking of the evidence. The sentence will probably be a death penalty and Rudolf is found guilty as quickly as possible by the jury and the court.

Even the family of Jim is questioning why he is defending a spy that wants to kill them with a nuclear bomb.  Jim asks the judge not to give Rudolf the death penalty as the USA may need to trade him in the future for an American spy who may be captured in the future.  Rudolf is convicted to serve 30 years in prison. The courtroom goes crazy as they wanted Rudolph to be executed.

Jim wants to appeal but his law firm and wife fight him to stop.  The public is so upset that someone shoots into Jims home and almost hits his daughter. His children are terrified. Jim goes onto the Supreme Court to defend Rudolf. They lose again with a 5 to 4 vote.

Francis David Powers is being recruited for a U2 pilot. He is told to die with his plane if shot down. They are given a suicide silver dollar with a poison pin. His plane is shot down on his first mission.  He fails to blow up the plane or to commit suicide. His cockpit cover rips off and he is jerked out of the pane before he can destroy it. This occurs in 1960.

The CIA wants Jim Donovan to negotiate the swap of the spies as an independent person. They want Jim to go to East Berlin. Legally he represents no one so he does not represent the USA. East Berlin is very dangerous at that time as they are building the Berlin Wall.  Jim lies to his wife and leaves for Europe on a secret CIA mission..

This is an excellent film. What else can you expect from Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks?  The casting of this film and the storyline and acting is first class. Having grown up when this was taking place makes this movie a repeat history lesson for someone at my age. We all knew the story of the U2 Crash in Russia and this film just brought back all of the fear between the superpowers during the Cold War.

Movies like this remind us why we should treasure our national heritage, remember what makes our country great, and be spurred to maintain that strength without wavering. I believe our nation was not only built by individuals like the man this film examines, we remain as a standard bearer of freedom throughout the world because such fine citizens are still found throughout this nation, raising familes, worshipping according to the dictates of their consciences, respecting the laws which govern us, and engaging in the political system we've inherited with the hopes of assuring a safe, secure, and prosperous future for our children. Please, please, please, stop tearing down this beautiful USA, and bring our nation's focus back to where it should be -- on the elements that, like this man's heroism, courage, and compassion, are worth emulating. This movie is one to watch with the whole family! I unreservedly recommend it.

Maybe Steven Spielberg's best movie.  The story follows an exchange of spies during the Cold War.  Tom Hanks is outstanding (as usual) as the everyday contracts lawyer who gets pulled into high stakes espionage between the US and the USSR.  No special effects, no explosions - just good story telling and a great cast.  Spielberg is somewhat "out of fashion" in Hollywood and was robbed at the Academy Awards for his movie Lincoln.  Bridge of Spies confirms his reputation as a top tier director who can command your attention throughout the entire movie.  First rate.

From Philadelphia to that stranded Island movie, I forget the name, from Road to Perdition; and onwards, his extensive, impressive career seriously never falters. And everyone knows this about Tom Hanks. He will be your hero. He will lead us home. He's got that voice, that sparkle in his eyes and that goodness of spirit, the camera simply cannot ignore.

When the movie starts, Donovan is a cunning Insurance lawyer and he immediately pulls you in with his quick thinking outsmarting the "other five guys", certainly not "his guy", who Donovan keeps saying isn't even "his guy".

Insurance claims litigation is like untangling a ball of wadded up silly string. Some fun!

Spielberg does something he is known for, he turns the tables on the viewer's emotions. We are supposed to hate that Russian spy. Oh, yes. Hate him and Hang him!-and yet, it becomes impossible (at least for me anyway), to have anything but overwhelming admiration for his stoicism and true fear for this man's fate.

Bridge of Spies is so relevant for today because it throws basic humanity back in our faces.
Are we truly so callous that we, THE  United States of America wouldn't even deign to try a man using the very Constitutional Rights we all live, vote, and breathe beneath? Are we such hedonistic cavemen, that our society has devolved to the point of no return?

Honestly, today, I look out at a strange society.
I turn on the news. I turn it off.
People are doing and saying things that nobody I ever knew would ever say or do. It feels as though at times, we are stuck in reverse, going backwards in our thinking expecting to rise up, only to devolve into an economically and socially divisive future that is threatening our very quality of life and the very way we as a country grow together. How we long for those good olden days. Not the segregated days, but rather better days when people were just people and though racism is a deep chasm and yes, it even involves democracy and spy movies (you better believe it), days when we were just a little kinder to one another. When you didn't need plexiglass at a gas station because the person who desperately needs that job is in real danger of getting shot. All for working at minimum wage. It makes no sense!

We all want something else. And yet, like it or not, we are all the same. Same beating hearts, same hurts, same tears in our eyes. Why can't we all see that?

When I get my tires checked, regular good guys are there with a kindness in thir eyes that reminds me, it's all okay, we're not really in that lost tv land of nomads and fire and brimstone.

This movie, Bridge of Spies, shows us just how good we all really do have it. It takes us to the Berlin wall and puts us on a train watching people getting shot to death, for trying to get to the other side.
Is THAT what we want in America? Our very own Berlin WALL??
Have we learned nothing?
People shooting people.
Is that who we want to become?
I kind of wish Bridge of Spies had waited to be released until right about now.

The bravery of James Donovan and what HE did for our country. And how ultimately, he saved so many prisoners, is a lauded story, one that I never knew. Schools should be talking about James Donovan and the great art of negotiation. Instead of the art of trash talk.

It's a movie you will cheer and cry to. And most importantly makes you feel like, YES!!! There is a Standing Man in this world!!-and makes you want to try hard to stand up for what you also believe in.

You can choose to hate the spy, or you can look at him as Donovan did, and ask, is he first, a human being?-and what of our own soldiers captured overseas?
If we cannot bestow humanity upon this spy, who are we as a nation?

I see this movie as an excellent example of diplomacy, negotiations and how countries work together even when those countries clearly hate each others guts. It would make an excellent class discussion and debate subject. Which no doubt is already occurring in schools across this country. I certainly hope so. Bravo Steven Spielberg. Bravo Tom Hanks. And such a heartwarming performance by Mark Rylance, Bravo!!!

This movie Bridge of Spies jumped out at me because it seemed like it would be a perfect film of intense suspense. My premonitions were correct and I unexpectedly became a little more informed during the movie about international relations. Tom Hanks stars as James B. Donovan., a character very much committed to upholding what the U.S. constitution stands for when it comes to his clients. Donovans life is turned dramatically upside down when he is assigned the case of Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance). This is because the character of Donovan is shown going through so much via having his life and that of his family in danger after he does his job of defending Abel (much to the chagrin of some the people who knew Donovan professionally). Despite extreme public condemnation, Donovan successfully fights for Abel with the argument that such a situation may set a precedent in the situation that an American is captured by the USSR.  Donovan experiences some redemption from professional criticism of what he advocated for Abel when Francis Powers (Austin Stowell) is captured by the USSR after his aircraft is shot down. Additionally, the film features an American college student named Frederic Pryor (Will Rogers) who was captured by the Eastern Germany police forces. However, Donovans work is far from done when this happens. I want to share more details in this review but I understand that I must take into account anyone seeing this who has not yet seen the film. Some of the Bonus Features of the film; a Case of the Cold War Bridge of Spies.

This is a review of Chasing Summits by Garry Harrington.  This is a great adventure book, very hard to put down.  I have read or listened to a lot of adventure/climbing books, but this is one of the best.  Garry's adventures tagging high peaks and the state high points across the U.S. are entertaining and even amusing at times.  Even an armchair climber can vicariously enjoy his descriptions of the difficulties he encounters on his summit attempts.  His travels to climb in Mexico and Central America take the reader to places that they most likely have never been to, and expose the  reader to new cultures and experiences.  I highly recommend this well written book for anyone who has ever looked at a mountain and wondered how it could be climbed.

Great story-telling!  Kept me on the edge of my seat.  Makes me want to read James Donovan's "Strangers on a Bridge," and study the transcripts from the associated Supreme Court hearings.  I'm not sure how much artistic license was used in either the book or movie, though the words offered by Mr Donovan in front of the Court cast a hugely positive light on the American spirit, if not the entire justice system writ large.

One non-film criticism is that "purchase" was the only option.  Please keep renting as an option, as very few films merit multiple viewings.  That said, I wish I would have purchased the version that included extras for the same price because I would love to know more about the background.

If you are looking for a spy vs spy action thriller, keep on walking.  But if you are interested in high-stakes drama and international intrigue during one of the most delicate times in 20th century history, then you are home.

Tom Hanks pulls off another powerful performance showing yet again that he is one of the premier actors of his generation.  Hanks, Spielberg and Rylance pull off a memorable, powerful experience.

Like some of you, I've heard people say, "It's too slow" or "It's boring" or "There's no action."  That's not the point of this movie at all.  It is all high suspense and a private citizen navigating an unknown new landscape in the aftermath of WWII in the eastern bloc under the shadow of the USSR and East Germany.

The acting is superb, the story line is engaging, and the experience is memorable.

For me this is a 5-star experience and I strongly encourage more than one viewing.  I've found that every time I've watched this film the more I've liked it and the more of it I've "gotten."
Watch this movie over and over.

My family lived in Berlin, Germany at the time of wall. I was 9 years old. My dad was in the Army. I had no idea that this was occurring, although tanks rumbling through the streets at all hours of the day and night was not the norm in the United States. Some things are somewhat out of place. Like there were lots and lots of bullet holes in the buildings that were still apparent then. That was not part of this drama, so really inconsequentially absent. But the spirits of the German people had as many bullet scars in them. Just as the people in the southern United States had for generations after the civil war.  No won wins in war, however necessary war may seem, or is.

I loved this movie. It has a great story, celebrates Tom Hanks talent as an outstanding actor, and it is a fascinating testimony of what Spielbergs ability of directing can achieve: wonderfully and meticulously arranged scenes create magic and suspense by artistically combining every aspect and craft involved in filmmaking. So, this amazing movie comes along as a captivating Renaissance/Baroque painting that powerfully makes use of light and shadow, skilfully matches the settings with the characters personalities and experiences, uses symbolism, subtle psychological amplifiers and realism in an elegantly arranged balance. It is a visceral dance based on the strong emotional undercurrents of the story that is presented with a delicate sense of timing. To me, in this motion picture, everything converged into a masterpiece: the grand, ancient tradition of storytelling presented as a multidimensional, interdisciplinary modern-day art form.

This was a very well done film with good acting, good direction, excellent screenplay and chilling cinematography. Mark Rylance gave the outstanding performance as the mild-mannered, beautifully understated soviet spy, Rudolf Abel, and Tom Hanks gave a wonderful performance as James Donovan. The only drawback for me was that the real story was amazing and inspiring all on its own, so I was sorry that Spiellberg felt it necessary to embellish at least in a couple of scenes to heighten the viewer's emotional response. I would have liked for Frederic Pryor's father to be at Checkpoint Charlie when his son was released (as he was). However, the story does convey the courage it had to have taken to stand up for what is right despite the critical pressure that stance may provoke. Bridge of Spies  is a gripping story, well worth viewing.

Tom Hanks plays Brooklyn lawyer James Donovan who gets drawn into the Cold War. He is selected by the bar association to represent Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance), a Soviet spy active in New York City. Donovan was chosen because no one wanted to defend Abel. Being an honest, honorable, and precise man, Donovan gives Abel the best defense he can, in spite of encouragement from family and the firm to get it done as quickly as possible. Donovan builds a little friendship with Abel, enough to find out that the U. S. government did try to get information from Abel or turn him into a double agent. Abel keeps quiet and refuses to cooperate, telling Donovan that the Americans have men just like Abel in Russia doing the same thing. The evidence is fairly overwhelming and the judge is completely unsympathetic, so the guilty verdict is no surprise.

Meanwhile, the U2 spy plane program has started. American pilots in Pakistan are flying U2 planes at 70,000 feet over Soviet airspace, taking pictures of facilities and other locations of interest to the U. S. Government. One of the planes is shot down and the pilot, Francis Gary Powers, is captured by the Soviets. Powers goes through a quick trial to parade him in front of cameras, showing how evil America is.

The two stories intersect when Donovan receives a letter from East Germany. Someone claiming to be Abel's wife has written and is hinting that they are willing to trade Powers for Abel. Donovan is drawn into the negotiations as an unofficial representative of the U. S. Government. That means he has to travel to Berlin just as the Berlin Wall is being constructed. An American graduate student is caught behind the eastern side of the wall and is held by the communist East German government. Donovan decides he wants to trade Abel for both Powers and the student, though the respective governments are not interested in extra complications. What follows is an exciting struggle by Donovan to get both the Americans home.

The movie is a sort of Cold War version of High Noon. Donovan is a man of integrity and uprightness, even in the face of social pressure to do the expedient and shallowly patriotic thing (either letting Abel go to the electric chair like the Rosenbergs did or accepting just Powers and not the student too). While he agrees the Cold War is a war of cultures, he insists that the Americans hold to their principles, like due process for Abel and protecting all lives including the student's. Otherwise, how is American culture different from Soviet culture?

Donovan is also intelligent and disciplined, able to read situations and either coax or strong-arm others into doing the right thing. Often, such actions are not convenient for Donovan but he does them anyway. He's an inspiring character.

Highly recommended!

Believe it or not, the master of cinematic wonder is still working strong. Steven Spielberg has met few close encounters towards failure in his career, but any time he did fail, he always got himself back up with his next project. We all know that he has recently met terrific success with the Civil War biopic Lincoln, and the World War I biopic War Horse, so now his big artistic success this time is the Cold War biopic Bridge of Spies. Noticing a theme here?

The big Spiels 28th feature tells about lawyer James B. Donovans (Tom Hanks) war on the worlds as he defends Rudolf Abel, the top spy of the Soviet Union. We see how he used this relationship to rescue a CIA pilot from the USSR, saving a life and in turn, the world entire. Does this story of the remarkable man of influence in the Cold War achieve what it needed to accomplish?

For the most part, yes. Steven Spielberg continues his line of smartly selected stories told as a wonderful tribute to the events depicted. As the unpredictable moments of Donovans journey hooks you in, you can feel his real life family brimming with smiles from the detail of the way that this Bronx lawyer and his accomplishments are highlighted. It is all done with the usual elements of a Spielberg film: blaring backlights, issues between a patriarchal father and his family, and explicit focus put on complex editing and cinematography techniques. Yet these trademarks of his vision are so subtle that you would even believe that this movie could have been directed by anybody.

But note how I above said for the most part. There are still a number of drawbacks that prevent this film from becoming a timeless classic that falls under Spielbergs long resume. While the films first half introduces character, conflict and setting flawlessly, the latter half drags with over usage of the Cold War vocabulary that would be difficult for the average IQ to comprehend. So if you did not live during the 1950s, and if you are unfamiliar with terms such as CIA U-2 spy-plane pilot or, KGB intelligence officer, and if the mechanics of the Soviet Union between Russia and the US are completely foreign to you, prepare to be horribly confused while thinking, 141 minutes. Why did it have to be 141 minutes?

Bridge of Spies is simply not a very personal filmodd since Steven Spielberg has been famously known for how much of himself he transpires to the public. E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial was a direct reflection of the divorce of his parents. Schindlers List stemmed directly from his Jewish roots. Saving Private Ryan was a tribute to his father. Bridge of Spies is merely a historical account from a point of history that Spielberg never felt many strong feelings towards.

While the films authoritative power many not been as strong as it could have been, a great round of applause should be made for the technical writing of Matt Charman and the Coen Brothers (Fargo, No Country for Old Men). This threesome opened the park with meticulous research done on every character and situation in this dense study on the Cold Wars meaning.

For the cinema bluffs out there, they should know that this movie, much like Spielbergs many other works with his usual editor Michael Khan (Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Raiders of the Lost Ark), makes for some highly provocative editing techniques. For instance, when Donovan is sitting in at the first of his court hearings to defend Abel, the judge makes the court stand for the pledge of allegiance. Immediately, the frame cuts to an elementary school classroom stating the pledge of allegiance, leading into a documentary on Russias nuclear bomb threat. The images of the documentary scar the kids pretty badly, one of them being Donovans son, who later at home learns that hell need a bigger bathtub as he fills his to the rim to preserve water in case the Russians did strike. Such a brief moment, and yet it marks such a wonderful touch of reality that sets the stage for the time.

But what is a winning set of filming techniques without a far more triumphant cast? The leading man Tom Hanks (Cast Away, Forrest Gump) plays the same natural strong-willed authoritative figure that is expected from an actor of his range. It is not the best of his career, but he still brings across precisely what was needed for the role without any hint of overplaying. Mark Rylance (Angels and Insects, Wolf Hall) also puts on an awards worthy performance as the Russian spy Rudolf Abel, and he even gets his moment of glory in a gorgeously paced monologue by the turning point between the first and second acts.

You know whats really sad about this film? It proves that Schindlers List was both the best and worst thing to happen to Spielbergs career. While it did show the world that he finally matured as an artist, none of his works after that, excluding one, became instant classics. Bridge of Spies is simply another addition to the batch. Yet even so, this film is an excellent display for the politically savvy viewer of what a finely tuned picture should look like, especially for those independent producers who are seeking to improve their art.

Overall Grade: A-

The movie is very close to a documentary of actual events, including the historical backdrop of the Glienicker Brcke in Potsdam near Berlin. Everyone living/growing up during the Cold War in/around Berlin in the late 1940's will re-live the awkward experience of those dark years during Walter Ulbricht's, and Konrad Adenauer's political careers.  This movie should become a staple in History classes, and Political Science courses.

This film is based on the FBI "hollow nickel" case. I liked this film despite its poetic licence with history. Donovan did not go to the judge's house to plead against Abel's execution - that was done in court, his home was never attacked, his coat was never stolen, he did not witness people being shot in attempting to scale the Berlin Wall and there was no Pryor's girlfriend. However, I didn't feel that those little fibs detracted from the film narrative. The "stolen coat" is a metaphor for Donovan's being closely watched. What I did find jarring was the scene in which Power's plane was shot down and his valiant attempt to reach the Destruct lever. That said, this is the story of a master negotiator, a seasoned deal maker who doesn't blink, and his dour, stoic and loyal client who chooses to wait on the bridge so that Donovan can get his other man. Hank's performance was great, but Mark Rylance was captivating, spell binding. His telling of the "standing man" story from his childhood was superb. This is not a film for action lovers - the magic is in the dialogue, the story, the characters, the settings, the ethics. Listen carefully as Donovan finds his way through the maze of competing political positions and deceptions, builds his case, bit by bit, outmanoeuvres his adversaries and holds his nerve. The "three endings" tied off the threads of duty, family, and ethics. The unspoken, smiling approval of the woman on the train, reading about the exchange of prisoners, subtly reflects the country's growing approval of Donovan, previously despised for defending Abel.
The acting was superb, especially by the actor who played the spy. Excellent job of telling a long story in a couple of hours and keeping it authentic at the same time very engaging.

Bridge of Spies is a Steven Spielberg-directed spy thriller that stars Tom Hanks, Mark Rylance, Austin Stowell, and Will Rogers. It tells the true story of how an obscure New York lawyer is recruited to negotiate an exchange of spies between the United States and the Soviet Union.

Four men are at the center of this fascinating and well-told story. Rudolf Abel (Rylance) is a Soviet intelligence agent working in New York City. In 1957, the FBI arrests Abel for espionage. He is quickly tried and convicted of the charges. Abels defense lawyer is James Donovan (Hanks), who previously had been requested for the job. Donovan reluctantly agrees to defend Abel. With all the anti-communist hysteria surrounding the case, he knows that its pretty much a foregone conclusion that Abel will be convicted. About the best Donovan can hope for is to convince the hard-nosed trial judge not to give his client a death sentence.

The third and fourth men in this story are Francis Gary Powers (Stowell) and Frederic Pryor (Rogers), two Americans serving time in separate prisons behind the Iron Curtain. Powers is a U-2 pilot working for the CIA. He had been shot down while flying over the Soviet Union. Pryor is a graduate student studying in Berlin, who just happens to be on the wrong side of the infamous wall then under construction. Their cases are about to become linked in a high stakes game of power politics between the worlds greatest superpowers

Re-enter James Donovan. The CIA recruits him to go into Berlin  by himself, and with no government backing  to negotiate an exchange of prisoners. The CIA wants an Abel for Powers-only swap. But on his own, Donovan decides to negotiate a two-for-one exchange: Abel for Powers AND Pryor

How will the CIA and the governments of the Soviet Union and East Germany react?  What will be the outcome? And what dangers does Donovan face while scurrying about in Berlin in search of a deal?  Watch this great film to find out

I really enjoyed Bridge of Spies. The film had just the right amount of tension to make it a first-rate spy thriller. As one might expect, all the actors are at the top of their game  especially Mark Rylance, who won the Best Supporting Actor Academy Award for his superb acting. Tom Hanks turns in another in a long line of outstanding, polished  performances as James Donovan.

Bridge of Spies is one of the best films of 2015, and one of my new favorites.. Highly recommended.

This has got to be one of the best films that capture the Cold War era of the 1950s.  Many of us who were children at the time can identify with Donovan's little boy who has filled up the bathtub and is lecturing his dad on why they should have a plan for the next drop of the atomic bomb in NYC!  What scary times!  I also remember seeing films of how to build a bomb shelter, what happens during a nuclear explosion, and  how we all need to be prepared.

Tom Hanks as Jim Donovan, the attorney that represented Colonel Abel, the Russian man convicted of espionage, did an excellent job portraying him.  The idea that Donovan had the foresight to recommend that this spy be spared execution because of a possible exchange in the future was brilliant!  How people reacted to the verdict was also predictable as WWII had ended, people lost relatives or had fought in this terrible war, and the thought of letting this man escape without paying the ultimate price was unthinkable.

Watching Donovan negotiate the release of two captives---one an American student in East Berlin and the other an American pilot were tense moments.  His ability to convince the Russians and East Germans to let both of these men go took someone of extraordinary bargaining skills.  And this guy was an insurance lawyer by profession!

The cinematography, especially the scenes of East Berlin, the Wall, and the representation of what happened to those who tried to climb over was well done and was overwhelmingly sad.  The bitter cold and the scene where Jim Donovan is accosted by some rough looking German young adults who end up stealing his coat was pretty intense!

This is a movie that will be appreciated by anyone who grew up in the Cold War era.  For those that didn't,  it's still an education and a history lesson about why Socialism and Communism are really not all they are cracked up to be!

Bridge of Spies, 2016 film

It begins in 1957 when America and Russia fear each other and hunt for spies. One man paints a self-portrait. His phone rings and he leaves. This is set in Brooklyn. Who is following him? The artist picks up a hidden item, then returns home to access the hidden message. G-Men break into his flat, question him, and search his rooms. Mr. Donovan is called to a meeting, they want him to defend an accused Soviet spy. Its a patriotic duty. Abel tells how he was offered money to work as a double agent. Donovan tells of his background. Do not talk to anybody else about your case. [Always good advice.] Then we meet Lt. Gary Francis Powers. He and others are selected for a mission that must be kept secret at all times. Lawyer Donovan asks for more time to prepare. [The too dark scenes make it hard to note the details.] He will not violate attorney client privileges.

In Pakistan the drivers are introduced to the article. It will take pictures from 70,000 feet, 2,000 square miles at a time. Was there a search warrant for what the FBI found? This rule goes back to 1886, even for an illegal immigrant. School children are exposed to warnings about nuclear warfare. [Mental conditioning?] Donovans son believes the newspaper reports. The jury votes guilty on all counts. Donovan asks for this to be set aside based on the weight of evidence. Abel is not afraid to die, but it wouldnt be his first choice. Abel tells about his past, his parents beating by partisan guards. Donovan talks to the judge at his home, he wants Abel kept alive. The judge sentences him to thirty years. [Did others meet the judge?] People object to this! Donovan will appeal. Shots are fired into Donovans home! [The Right to Keep and Bear Arms was operational even in Brooklyn then.] He will get protections. The drivers get instructions on destroying the article, and themselves. Spend the dollar. Donovan argues before the Supreme Court, using the analogy to the military.

In 1960 Lt. Powers U-2 was shot down by a rocket. He cannot hit the destruct button. The news carries misinformation about a weather plane that went off-course. The appeal by Donovan is denied. In the USSR Powers is sentenced to prison. Allen Dulles learns about the letter from East Germany. Will there be a prisoner exchange? Donovan must go to East Berlin to negotiate; will he? The Berlin Wall is built (to control immigration). Donovan will go to Europe on a routine business trip. The US wants Powers out, Donovan gets instructions. Young men give Donovan directions and take his overcoat! Donovan meets Abels relatives, then an official, to explain the exchange. Prisoner Powers is questioned about details on his article, but he knows little. Donovan continues his negotiations for Powers and Pryor. They meet at the Glienicke Bridge early in the morning. Abel is unemotional; he can wait. Then the exchange of items is made. Donovan returns home. The news tells of the exchange. Abels sentence was commuted by the President, so it was all legal. Donovan was later sent to Cuba to negotiate the release of 9,703 men, women, and children. [No mention of later events.]

This is more of a history lesson not entertainment, so it is not dramatic. It runs on too long and has too many dark scenes. Few will remember these events from nearly sixty years ago, so this is worth watching. Abel seems to have been a courier who gathered reports from other spies for retransmission without knowing much about the source. This is done so the identities remain hidden. Machines (satellites) have replace humans in reconnaissance. As I remember it, Powers did not use the destruct button because it would have caused an instantaneous explosion to eliminate everything. This was not done in WW II to protect the Norden bombsight.

Overall, I thought that the movie was very suspenseful and I did enjoy watching the movie. The movie has some historical facts, but if you do your research you will find that the timeline in the movie does not follow the actual timeline of events.

I've always been a Tom Hanks fan and I thought he did a decent job in this movie. I thought he portrayed the character very well despite the Hollywood effect on the actual true story of which the movie is inspired from.

Language wasn't overly terrible and there were no sex scenes, but there is a scene where someone is shot and killed, which will be too graphic for children.

Overall a decent movie and one I wouldn't mind watching again. However, don't fully believe everything in this movie as fact. If you want to know the actual story, just do a little research and you'll see the differences.

Bridge of Spies tells the story of a US-USSR prisoner exchange at the height of the Cold War in the early 1960s. The film is based partly on the James B. Donovans memoir Strangers on a Bridge (1964) and features an all-star creative team. It was written by Joel and Ethan Coen and Matt Charman and directed by Stephen Spielberg. In 1960, a man calling himself Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) is arrested in New York on suspicion of espionage for the Soviet Union. The Brooklyn Bar Association approaches James Donovan (Tom Hanks), an insurance lawyer who worked on the Nuremberg trials, to represent Abel in court out of concern that the US give the appearance of a fair trial. Donovan accepts in spite of his wifes reservations and earnestly tries to protect Abels civil liberties, not knowing that his involvement in the case will lead him deep into Cold War intrigue.

The details are not all accurate, but Bridge of Spies provides drama and an outline of what happened when the two Cold War superpowers held each others countrymen and wanted them back. Mutual mistrust and East Germanys independent agenda made negotiations over the fate of Rudolf Abel and American U2 pilot Francis Gary Powers (Austin Stowell) difficult. The film largely tells the story from Donovans point of view; hes the hero. But it gives the audiences snippets of the early days of the U2 spy plane program, which would fly into Soviet airspace to take aerial photographs, because the two storylines eventually collide. Very much in the Hollywood style, filmmakers went out of their way to make Powers young, dashing, and handsome.

This is a solid Hollywood-style drama, with a few incongruities. Abel was a communist ideologue and loyal Soviet who had been an important intelligence agent during World War II. He is presented in the film as being a realist, almost a fatalist, with a very subdued personality. I don't know if the conversations depicted in the film are accurate. As written, Abel didn't impress me as an ideologue. Just the opposite. Tom Hanks has made a career playing low-key everyman protagonists, the flip side of the same coin as Harrison Ford, who made a career playing everyman action heroes. But James Donovan was in his early 40s when these events took place, and Tom Hanks is conspicuously older. Tom Hanks is good in the role, but Hollywood needs to start thinking about who is going to fill his shoes. With an undeniable Hollywood gloss, the film is entertaining and thoughtful.

I was serving in West Germany during the time covered in he film. It was incredible how the film brought back all the memories of that time. Tom
Hanks was (as usual) great as the official go-between of the spy swap. Even though we all knew how this turned out, the film was so well-directed, acted and scripted, that the viewer became lost in the intrigue.

Many Americans are unaware that East Berlin existed for many years after the end of WW II as a "movie set" with buildings on the main street, Unter den Linden, mere facades with nothing behind them but bombed out rubble. It would have been easy for the film to gloss over that fact, but it truly depicted the situation. The tenseness between the Russians and the East German police was real and it's a miracle that the swap was completed without incident. Great movie.  Highly recommended.

This is an excellent movie.  The middle and late fifties were very bleak times in terms of politics.  Many of us may have had some good times back then, but the tension of the 'cold war' was difficult for those of us who were aware.  I can recall the 'duck and cover' drills as well as retreats to the basement of our school building.  We heard something about 'civil defense,' but much of these exercises was mysterious.  The development, regarding the Soviet "spy," superbly played by Mark Rylance,  was gripping.  After his initial court hearing, the overall plot comes on perhaps too quick, as Powers comes  conveniently into the picture  (as I knew in advance basically what to expent).  With terrific acting, the covert, nasty 'intelligence' issues are unnerving, especially understanding that these games are still routine among many nations.
Not the best from either Tom Hanks or Steven Spielberg, but it was still very good.

The feel of this movie is just right.  It transports you back to a simpler, yet more uncertain, time during the Cold War years.  I have an affection for the setting and the backdrop as it reminds me so much of my childhood.  All the details are intricately accurate from the cars to the homes, clothing styles, television sets, dinner tables, etc.  The film looks as though it was shot in 1957!  Plus Spielberg knows how to use the camera to frame things and keep you engaged.  In the hands of any other director, the film would have suffered.  Instead, we're given a terrific drama that keeps you mesmerized.  It mixes the right amount of humor, action, historical accuracy, drama, and suspense.
Overall, found it to be alittle thin...was expecting alot more...was worth watching but not one I'd add to my collection

PLOT: Lawyer Donovan defends Commy Spy Rudolf Abel~ and later....helps trade him for downed U2 Pilot Francis Gary Powers~ 5 STAR all the way.

1957~ We see a mousy little man painting in NY City~ he is clearly being followed and watched~ he also picks up a DEADDROP coin hidden under his bench. He goes back to his shabby apartment where is opens the coin and a message in code is hidden inside.. Soon FBI and CIA break down his door and arrest him for being a "Commy Spy".....The man is Rudolph Abel and is not everyone's idea of a spy from being small and elderly to his over sided glasses. But he is clever enough to ask to clean up his paints and at the same time destroys the message by globing paint on it while the FBI /CIA search his apartment for Clues........ Enter Jim Donovan (TOM HANKS) an insurance investigator who helped prosecute Nazis at Nuremberg. He is appointed as the Public Defender for Spy Abel. Donovan is stuck being the SECOND most hated man in America AFTER Abel. He puts up a good defense but the Communist Scare at the time only helps convict Abel. Donovan suggests to the judge that Abel might be later "exchanged" and is a valuable asset since he is a Colonel in the KGB. Pilot Francis Gary Powers is part of the Ultra Secret U2 flights over Russia to spy from the air using high tech cameras to film and collect info from the USSR. Powers is shot down and is soon being interrogated. A Communist "show trial" has him convicted and in prison for years for being a Spy against the USSR /Russia.  A Letter from East Germany arrives for Abel at Donovan's Law office~ and begins  the "plot" to exchange Abel for Powers is soon being planned.  Donovan is the Key ~He is the 'go between'...between the Communists and the Americans and the East Germans where the exchange is to take place~~ Donovan gets the run around in East Germany~ and realizes he is a pawn between the Soviets and the East Germans both hoping to trade someone for Abel. Donovan decides he has had enough and turns the tables. The East Germans are attempting to gain POWER in this deal~ Added to the mix is a third American prisoner Donovan "demands" Both American Prisoners for Abel. and the Bridge of Spies from East Germany to West along with the Russians takes place. Hanks is first rate as the man who always does the right thing. HISTORICAL FOLLOW UP ON DONOVAN~JFK used Donovan again to later broker a deal with CASTRO to exchange "money and humanitarian aid" for Prisoners from the Bay of Pigs fiasco. this is an excellent movie. This story unfolds and shows the Commy Scare times of the late 1950s in America complete with Drills for Atom Bomb Attacks ~ also watch the Bonus feature on this DVD with behind the scenes from Hanks and Speilberg. 5 STARS~ and scene stealer here is Abel (MARK RYLANCE) as the spy who knows everything but tells nothing and the emerging respect he has for Donovan. This movie is based on real life events and the Bio of Donovan.

It's based on a real-life story about negotiations.  But they're not very long ones.  There's a lot of what feels like padding.  I mean yeah, it establishes the stakes and tone and sets the scene.  But it's also too much of the movie, IMO.
I was pretty inspired and loved these characters, so it sure did something right.  But still, it's a quieter piece of history and the movie reflects that for better or worse.  If you want excitement, this may not be for you.  But if you want to see Tom Hanks do what he does, show you the power of conscience, it delivers exactly that.  I'm on the fence between 3 and 4 stars.

For those who like their history all polished up and fast moving, well, they will not be terribly thrilled with this.  For the rest of us who realize life isn't a fast paced affair, this movie rolls in and unfolds at the pace of the Thaw of the Cold War.

James 'Jim' Donovan, an insurance attorney, is asked to defend purported Soviet Spy Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) in a court of law.  Upon reading a guilty verdict Donovan speaks to the sentencing judge asking that the death penalty be taken off the table in hopes of using Abel as a potential future bargaining chip.  At the same time the CIA is recruiting U-2 pilots from the Air Force.  Enter Francis Gary Powers.  Exit Powers, if you know what I mean.

The rest of the movie centers on Donovan's attempt to not only trade Abel for Powers with the Soviets but trade Abel for incarcerated Berlin University student American Frederick Pryor (Will Rogers) with the East Germans who have recently erected the Berlin Wall and are trying desparately to be seen as a legitimate government by the U.S.

This is a slow moving chess game or cat andmost have by all parties involved.

Over time, Spielberg's fascination with the visual aspect of iconic- historical scenes, have grown to the point where there is not much space left for anything else. Why waste words when they might distract from the visual epic cinematography? For Spielberg, the moral and political complexities involved in the characters' actions, are far too murky and far less attractive to be truly dealt with. The paranoia and xenophobia  which penetrate both sides of the cold war are barely mentioned before quickly passed on to introduce another cinematic moment. How did each of the exchanged parties fare by their colleagues, their families and the public? Were they revered or reviled, and for what reasons?  And how did they see themselves? We never get more than a glimpse into the minds of the real two (or three) dramatic characters. Looking back - Is there any part we could or should be ashamed of in the way the pilot was treated? You will not get any contribution to the above by this film creator.
PLEASED WITH MY PURCHASE.

A fun script, inspiring story, and great performances made this probably my favorite rental of the year.  Tom Hanks is in his wheelhouse as conscientious Everyman James B. Donovan, who is somehow deadly serious about doing the right thing without taking himself too seriously.  In fact, I think this is the character's key feature, as his affable nature and keen intelligence play against the Cold War background of dark and affected gravitas on both sides of the Iron Curtain to amazing effect, making for several wonderful laugh-out-loud moments in a film that was played entirely straight.  A great commentary on how ludicrous and shallow the greatest and deadliest of human conflicts can be, while also warming the heart and reminding us that we can make a difference.

I have always had a weakness for the Cold War espionage stories and the players involved in them. The Glienicke Bridge in particular, is a critical part of this lore. The bridge linked West Berlin and communist East Germany's city of Potsdam. This was where the East and the West traded their spies in exchange.  These exchanges started soon after  the Berlin Wall came up and continued all the way up to the collapse of Communism in 1990. This movie is about the first-ever such exchange made on this bridge in 1962. The USSR traded the U2-fighter pilot Gary Powers in return for their spy Rudolf Abel.  The film is a wonderful thriller, albeit in a moody, low-key way. It is devoid of any action-packed chases or gun-induced violence.  Still, it emerges as a  gripping drama,  enriched by the personalities of Rudolf Abel and his Defence lawyer John Donovan. It is yet another good one from Steven Spielberg.

The story unfolds with the FBI capturing Rudolph Abel in NYC and charging him as a Soviet spy. The US decides to appoint John Donovan, an insurance lawyer in NYC, to act as Abel's defence lawyer. Donovan's expected role was rather modest. He just needed to show that even spies get 'fair play' in the US. This was supposed to be in contrast to the 'summary executions' which take place in the USSR under similar circumstances.  But, Donovan tries in earnest, even though his defence of Abel fails in the Supreme Court. In the charged atmosphere of the 1960s, a clamour rises for sentencing Abel to death. Everyone from the presiding judges to the ordinary man on the street wants it. The public denounces Donovan for defending a Soviet spy. Donovan ignores all the criticism and argues with the judge to reduce the sentence to life. With great foresight, he suggests that it may be useful to keep Abel alive in US' own interests. There might arise a situation where the USSR takes an American as prisoner. A living Abel would be useful in exchanging him for the American. Just as Murphy's law dictates, Gary Powers, a young American pilot, flies an U2 spy plane over the USSR and is shot down. The Russians capture him as a spy. Following this, a second American also gets arrested in East Berlin.  He was Frederic Pryor,  a 23-year old student, who finds himself on the wrong side of the Berlin Wall. The CIA enters the picture and asks Donovan to negotiate on behalf of the US for a prisoner exchange. Cold-War pride dictates that the US cannot acknowledge that such negotiations are taking place.  So, there will not be any overt support from the administration. The rest of the film follows the efforts of Donovan in a cold East German winter.  He negotiates with the Soviet apparatchiks as well as the CIA. We see the ugly side of the CIA. False ideological pride makes American officials to focus only on Powers' release.  They feel that Pryor would complicate the Abel-Powers exchange and argue with Donovan to ignore Frederic Pryor in this negotiation. But Donovan would have none of it.  He would negotiate only for the simultaneous release of both Americans for Abel. In this, he finds a most unlikely ally in Rudolf Abel. It all converges towards a fascinating ending.

It is refreshing to see the subject of a Soviet spy treated without jingoism. The screenplay shows Donovan arguing that Abel is an honorable man. He doesn't reveal any intelligence under interrogation. He does exactly what the US  itself would expect of its own spies. The film shows that even in the 1960s, there was the desire to condemn Abel without trial. After all, it was the time when Joe McCarthy and the Rosenbergs were recent memories. But, Donovan emphasizes  the importance of 'due process as per the Constitution' in Abel's trial. And it is interesting to see that he managed to prevail when paranoia was still rampant. It is tempting to see the film as a commentary on the conduct of the US in this era of being the sole superpower. Today, we have mass surveillance on law-abiding citizens. We have the endorsement of torture of prisoners in the name of 'containing Terrorism'. But the 'Red Peril' of the 1960s was so much more dangerous and powerful than a bunch of fanatical terrorists. Still, it was not possible then to tap a phone call without a court order. Nor was it possible for the State to open our mails without due permission.

Mark Rylance, the British actor, plays the role of Abel and he is just magnificent.  In the long opening sequence of the film, the FBI agents trail him and arrest him in his drab and dreary flat. Here, Rylance plays Abel as a consummate, smooth, unperturbed spy with great skill. In the courtroom, we see an Abel who is subdued, inscrutable and devoted to his cause and principles. The courtroom action moves on and the threat of a  death sentence hovers over his head. Here, we see an Abel with quiet humor and a philosophical detachment. He is excellent in the final scene on the Glienicke bridge as well. Tom Hanks, as John Donovan, gives another excellent performance.  He brings the nondescript insurance lawyer into a real-life hero figure.

BRIDGE OF SPIES [2015 / 2016] [Blu-ray + Digital HD ULTRAVIOLET] [UK Release] Inspired By True Events! Magnificent Cold War Thriller! One of Steven Spielbergs Finest Films!

A dramatic thriller set against the backdrop of a series of historic events. Directed by three-time Academy Awards winner Steven Spielberg BRIDGE OF SPIES. Tells the story of James Donovan [Tom Hanks], an insurance claims lawyer from Brooklyn who finds himself thrust into the centre of the Cold War when the CIA enlists his support to negotiate the release of a captured American U-2 pilot. High stakes and suspense power of a story that is inspired by the true events that captures the essence of a man who risked everything, and that vividly brings his personal journey to life.
