Andrews Blu-ray Review: BRIDGE OF SPIES [2015] is a truly finely magnificent crafted, beautifully acted spy thriller film that offers the viewer intrigue, mystery and danger. Its based on a true story and some of the key points of the film were shot on the very locations where the incidents took place.

Tom Hanks portrays lawyer James B. Donovan who is asked to take on a criminal case and even though he hasn't done so for years. This one is important though, so he agrees, even though he knows it will make him the second most vilified man in America. The most vilified is the man hes representing Rudolf Abel [Mark Rylance] a man who is believed to be a Russian spy, despite his British accent and home base in Germany.

Mark Rylance turns in a total awe inspiring excellent performance, worthy of his Awards, understated performance of a quiet, unassuming man whose main hobby is painting. Thats just what hes doing when the Feds bust in to his apartment and arrest him. He quietly complies, and when he meets Rudolf Abel for the first time, he is just as quiet and compliant, despite the fact that hes facing the electric chair. As he tells Rudolf Abel numerous times, Would worrying help? James B. Donovan grows to like Rudolf Abel, who, if a threat to the United States seems docile and meek.

This is set during the Cold War, a time when director Steven Spielberg was growing up, and he really nails the emotion of the time period and the sentiment among Americans. They were terrified that a bomb would drop on the United States of America that would kill them all, or at the very least, deprive them of basic necessities, such as water. James B. Donovans son, after watching an instructional film at school as to what to do if the Soviets drop a bomb, is terrified and fills the bathtub full of water in preparation. The rest of America is just as on edge, and when James B. Donovan accepts Rudolf Abels case, his entire family becomes a target.

Tom Hanks brings a quiet strength to his character where James B. Donovan is a moral man who cares very much about the welfare of other people. He doesnt see Rudolf Abel as a threat, but as a man doing what his country ordered him to do. Rudolf Abel believes lives are more important than politics and his persistence plays a very big role in what comes about when an American pilot Francis Gary Powers [Austin Stowell] is captured by Russia, and Frederic Pryor [Will Rogers] a young American man studying in Germany is taken into custody just as the Berlin wall is going up.

Theres a scene at the end, when James B. Donovan is on a train, that mirrors an earlier moment he had on a train while in Europe. James B. Donovan saw something horrifying and what he spots brings back that memory. Its a brilliant, moving way to end the film, and while watching, I wondered if it was the brainchild of the screenwriters or the director. It was neither. While watching the bonus features, I learned that Tom Hanks came up with the idea and presented it to Steven Spielberg, who liked it and agreed to end the film that way. So all in all this is a totally amazing spy thriller film that keeps you on the edge of your seat, even though you know the final outcome.

Blu-ray Video Quality  20th Century Fox and DreamWorks presents this amazing Blu-ray disc with feast for all your senses, that is abounding in clarity that far exceeds the theatrical presentation of the film. All elements of all planes of every image are in constant focus. Colours, particularly the blacks and blues, are luscious, nearly viscous, suggesting tangible extra dimensions within the frame. Whites often affirm the film's theme of truth as existing in shards, splintering images, especially the white light reflecting off of the heavy rain in a notably expressionist chase scene. Textures are tactile, from the coats worn by the characters to the various tools of espionage used by agents to the gears and gadgets within the U-2 plane.

Blu-ray Audio Quality  20th Century Fox and DreamWorks presents this amazing Blu-ray disc with a totally brilliant awe inspiring 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio soundtrack aurally complements the hyper-detail of the imagery, often abounding in subtle exaggerations of everyday noises: of a rumbling train jostling riders on their daily commute, of the aforementioned raindrops hitting the pavement, of feet tramping across a shabby floor, of a spy delicately removing a razor to open a hidden piece of information. This presentation celebrates the beauty of exacting density.

Blu-ray Special Features and Extras:

Special Feature: A Case of the Cold War: Bridge of Spies [2015] [1080p] [1.78:1] [17:45] Filled with archival footage/audio, interviews with the actors, director, writer, historian and the real people from the story, this is the first of the features to serve as a history lesson for the real events and shows what was happening in the world in the late 1950s, when there was tension between Russia and the U.S.A and there was a very real threat of war. Francis Gary Powers Jr. talks about his fathers beginnings and how he became a pilot. With American student Frederic L. Pryor reveals what he went through in East Germany when the Berlin wall went up. We discover that Francis Gary Powers trial is re-enacted in the film word for word from the actual trial. Following Rudolph Abel return to Russia, to be reunited with his wife and daughter, Rudolph Abel was never publicity acknowledged by the Soviet Union as a spy. Francis Gary Powers died in a helicopter crash in 1977, while working for KNBC News. Francis Gary Powers were posthumously awarded the CIA Directors Medal and the USAF POW Medal in 2000 and the Silver Star in 2012. In 1962, Frederic L. Pryor received his Ph. D. in Economics from Yale University and now Frederic L. Pryor is currently Professor Emeritus of Economics and Senior Research Scholar of Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania, U.S.A. Following the successful conclusion of the Powers-Abel exchange, James B. Donovan was asked by President John F. Kennedy to undertake further negotiations on behalf of the U.S.A. In the summers of 1962, James B. Donovan was sent to Cuba to discuss with Fidel Castro the terms of the release of 1,113 prisoners held after the failed Bay of Pigs invasion. When James B. Donovan finished negotiations, James B. Donovan secured the release of 9,703 men, women and children.

Special Feature: Berlin 1961: Re-Creating the Divide [2015] [1080p] [1.78:1] [11:35] Kicking off with a history lesson of the time, this feature explains how the Berlin locations were re-created in actual Berlin and how many of the actual locations were re-dressed to match the time. Tom Hanks talks about the historical aspect of filming in East Germany where the actual events took place. Archive footage of the time shows young people trying to get through barbed wire to get to freedom. American technical consultant Jane R. Helmchen, who worked in West Germany as a teacher just after the wall was built, talks about how difficult it was to get through to East Germany from West Germany at the time. We see how parts of East Berlin were recreated for the film, because modern day Berlin is much too different now, and Marc Platt [Producer] says that they located to the Polish town Wroc'aw, that they found to have Berlin 1961 architecture that was totally perfect to recreating Berlin in 1961. Near the end of this special feature you see Tom Hanks on the New York Subway travelling to work and Tom Hanks looks out of the window to see young men jumping over fences in some different neighbours back gardens, and the same time you see young men and women trying to climb over the Berlin Wall and being shot by the East German Guards, which Tom Hanks suggested to director Steven Spielberg, who thought it was a perfect solution and to actually see this near the end of the film.

Special Feature: U-2 Spy Plane [2015] [1080p] [1.78:1] [8:45] With full D.O.D. cooperation, actual U-2 spy planes were used for the film's shoot l. The ground and take-off footage was captured with fully functional and still-in-use U-2 planes. The in-flight stunt sequences were obviously shot with mechanised set pieces and a CGI backdrop, which is also shown in this feature. This gives you a look at what it took to film the scenes involving the pilots. Francis Gary Powers Jr. reveals that he worked as a technical consultant as well as an extra on the film and was very proud to honour his Father, Francis Gary Powers and Francis Gary Powers Jr. comments that this film is a great legacy for future generations, in knowing what actual happened in those dark days in 1961s Cold War scenario. In a rare audio voice over, his Father, Francis Gary Powers, describes what happened within his plane after he was shot down.

Special Feature: Spy Swap: Looking Back on the Final Act [2015] [1080p] [1.78:1] [5:42] Here with the film's climax, we witness the actual location where we have the prisoner exchange scene was filmed on the Glienicke Bridge (the so-called "Bridge of Spies"), where the historical exchange actually took place in 1962. The bridge spans the Havel narrows between Berlin and Potsdam, and was closed to traffic for filming over the last weekend of November. German Chancellor Angela Merkel visited the set to watch the filming of these scenes. Principal photography officially ended on December 4, at Berlin Tempelhof, where it unfolded and see how the location was shot to make the bridge become more than just a location setting, but a character within the film. The bridge swap is re-enacted on the actual bridge where the exchange took place. Once again we hear a rare voice recording of Francis Gary Powers talking about being imprisoned in Russia. Francis Gary Powers Jr. reveals to us that his Father, Francis Gary Powers wasn't aware of what was being reported about him at the time in the U.S.A. press and some were saying that he had defected and told the Russians all the information he knew about the technical details of the U-2 Spy Plane, and was planning to live there, none of which was true. Frederick L. Pryor informs us about the actual real time in 1961 when he was going to be swapped at the same time as Rudolph Abel, but in reality had to sit in the car for hours and was not informed on what was going on., especially with the East German authorities. All in all, this was quite a fascinating and interesting special feature, especially seeing the behind-the-scenes of the last days of shooting the BRIDGE OF SPIES film, in recreating the actual event on the historic Berlin bridge.

Special Feature: Credits [2015] [1080p] [1.78:1] [1:03] This particular item is entitled BRIDGE OF SPIES DOCUMENTARIES and it gives complete information on all the people who were involved with the four special feature documentaries.

Finally, BRIDGE OF SPIES [2015] is a totally grippingly engrossing and expressive espionage yarn, another exemplary entry in Steven Spielberg's late-career period, receives a top-tier, must-buy transfer. What makes it great is that it's an entirely perfect package. From the acting, the directing to writing, the lighting, and every single aspect of it is totally flawless. It's a perfectly oiled machine in which all of the moving parts function with great precision. The extremely accurate true story is one that is totally entertaining to watch and especially unfolding before your eyes. You will be totally surprised that you have not heard of this real-life Cold War story until now. The Blu-ray features perfect video and audio experiences, making this even more of a perfect package. While the Blu-ray disc could have benefited from a higher quantity of special features, those that are included are of great quality, as well of great interest and will satisfy those who want to know more historical information about the era in which it is set in in 1961, and the true story upon which the film is based, and how the film adaptation was realized. If you haven't yet seen this six-time Oscar nominated highly rewarding film, then it is definitely must own for your Steven Spielberg Blu-ray Collection. Very Highly Recommended!

We all remember, from our history text books at least, the events from 1957 to 1962, the total hysteria of the USA about Soviet spies which had led to McCarthyism and the execution of the Rosenberg husband and wife. The fall of Cuba out of their zone or sphere of influence was a trauma they are just right now trying to put behind. The spying was primitive with those spying planes that had no chance what-so-ever to get through: the first one was the last one. On both sides they ended up with spies in their prisons kept nicely warm to be used in some political negotiations as leverage.

Consider the case of a Soviet spy in New York and that of an American pilot of a spying plane shot down over the USSR, plus the fact that East Germany turned tricky and led to the construction of the wall, and to top it all like the cherry of the cake one nave American student preparing his PhD on communist economic policy in eastern Europe was at the wrong place at the wrong moment and got arrested and prosecuted as a spy by the East Germans. But the East Germans hated the Russians who had for sure liberated them from Hitler, but who had also destroyed Berlin in the most ruthless way possible, though the Palace of the Hohenzollern was pulled down by the East Germans.

Tricky situation indeed to negotiate the release of two Americans, one of whom is a real security risk in exchange of one Soviet spy. And it took some time and a lot of patience, including against the CIA who only wanted to recuperate the security hazard out of Soviet hands before he cracked. It took a lawyer from Brooklyn, a pure Irish descendant to manage to bridge the two or three divides to get what he wanted. All those among you who have actually lived this period will remember the stress, the danger, the fear amplified by what the film does not tell: the Bay of Pigs debacle in 1961 and the Soviet missile crisis in Cuba in 1962. We went through a few years of absolute scare about the possibility of a nuclear war.

We can have a nostalgic look at the past. I was in East Berlin and East Germany for the first time in 1963. I worked in a mine near Leipzig then, in Borna. There will be more trips. The most dramatic will be in 1968 after the Soviet intervention in Czechoslovakia. My own son will go once in the 1980s I just wonder how Donovan managed to get lost when coming out of Friedrichstrasse Bahnhof which is practically round the corner to Unter den Linden. Well some must have some fun now and then. And it only cost him a coat and a cold.

We can also measure the immense change we have been through: reunited Germany; united Europe (nearly finished though Russia will always be on the side); free and emerging Vietnam; China the second economic power in the world; apartheid gone with the wind; Cuba accepted anew  by the USA; the banana republics of South America also gone. And yet the dangerous places have just moved to other areas and mostly because of the dumb policy of one US president who decided to solve the problem he had with his own father by proving to the world the USA could create havoc in the Middle East, and they did. And North Korea is the answer of the shepherdess to the shepherd: a perverted and fouled love song that prolongs the Korean War that was a total failure in the objective of the time to get Mao Zedong and the Communists in China down.

Is the world really a better place today than it was in 1957-1962? You have to be nave to believe that. The main difference is that spying is no longer that crucial and it has been replaced by the protection of intellectual property against pirating. Pirates and Hackers are the two plagues or our modern world. More than ever the danger is no longer from the outside but from the inside. Lets move our minds and backsides a little bit and lets clean up the mess Bush Jr. did and all European countries, especially the super-duper secular ones who pretend that everyone has the right to be a Muslim, a Jew or a Christian, or whatever, provided it is kept absolutely invisible in the public sphere, are today confronted to the bill.

Dematerialization and castration of at least two generations of immigrants in Europe from previously colonized countries, which means at least three, four or more centuries of colonial alienation, exploitation and extermination when necessary leading to uprooting them from their countries and transporting them into countries that refused to recognize and respect the fact that they are different. As the fundamentalist secularists would say: They can believe in what they want provided I do not see it. And the hazardous population is not outside but inside our borders. We have walled them up in our backyard without any rights whatsoever as for opinions and religions.

The old Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome we all in Europe inherited from centuries of wars and the two world wars was turned into a Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome called the Cold War and we are still in that mood. We see the danger outside when it is inside, and not inside our territory only but inside our minds. The new situation is that the PTSS of the Cold War is confronted today to the Post Traumatic Colonial Stress Syndrome of the uprooted millions of previously colonized people who we have brought in our countries for salaried slavery. And we think that by mocking the religion of these human beings who are suffering in their inner essence we will free them of their PTSS. Only Charlie can be that dumb. I am sure that kind of anti-empathetic attitude would have turned the 1957-1962 situation into a holocaust. And thats the real danger today. The Islamic State will be defeated but what do we do afterwards? Cartoons of the Prophet dicing onions? And I am trying hard to remain polite. I guess some secular fundamentalists do think so. Papaoutai? Really this time. [...]

Based on a true story, this is an extremely sure-footed tellling of the prisoner exchange between the US and the Soviet Union, with the East German government operating as a partner to th Soviet government. Tom Hanks is exceptional as the lawyer who is representing the Soviet spy in court, and becomes the sole American negotiator for the spy exchange. The script is terrific, the set design, costuming, and cinentaography all recreating the period in outstnading fashio, and Steven SPielberg's direction is to the point, making the plot beats hit home moment after moment. I highly recommend this film to all interested in cinematic depictions of recent historical events.

I was pretty young when Gary Powers crashed so I did not remember many of the details.  This was a fascinating movie and extraordinary patriotism by Tom Hanks' character.

It starts a little slow but hang on as the plot unfolds and it is revealed how a lawyer from NY does what seems very unlikely at first as he works to get Gary Powers released in a swap deal.  It gets even more unlikely after he decides to negotiate the release of a second US student, in opposition to the the US government agents, in a two for one swap.

Although I don't know if it was 100% true the story shows the human side of being enemies.  There is a sub-plot of how the trust between the main character and the Russian spy develops and plays out all the way to the end as the spy adds his own little twist to ensure the US student is also released.

This is the retrospective version of a pivotal point in history of a spy exchange and the man James B. Donovan played by Tom Hanks who facilitated to make it possible.

I grew up in the era and remember the papers from the time. I followed it in U.S. News & World Report; at that time it was quite informative and not an echo of Time and Newsweek.

When I heard about this film I could not resist as it has great actors, producer, and director. Not to mention the consultants. You already know that Tom Hanks is good at what he does; however I was impressed with Mark Rylances portrayal of Rudolf Abel.

The movie production itself has great scenes and costumes of the time that make it fascinating from start to finish. You feel that you are there. There is a speech, not quite as long as an Ayn Rand speech that remides us what makes us Americans.

The actual story comes off a tad different then memory. Actuarially a tad better and I never received the full picture. Until I read different this will be my impression of the time.

The presentation I watched did not offer a voice-over commentary. I hope a future version will.
Not as Google as I thought it would be. Maybe I expected more.

Set during the height of the cold-war the film depicts the tensions and suspicions at .a time when many believed
there were 'reds in the bed' so to speak, and questioned any and all strange behaviour patterns, the world at large
was afraid of it's own shadow.
When a suspected Spy 'Rudolf Abel' (Mark Rylance) is apprehended it becomes necessary if but just to demonstrate
that proper procedure is followed in the eyes of the World an American lawyer is recruited 'James B Donovan' (Tom
Hanks) to defend the accused in court even though the outcome was never in doubt.
'James B Donovan' had been given a 'poison-challis' a case he could not win, a case that would attract wide-spread
publicity, a case that would if but initially make him a subject of hatred from the public at large.
He defends his client to the best of his ability and will argue that rather than issue a death-penalty on 'Rudolf Abel'
it would be a wise choice to keep him alive and perhaps use him in a future prisoner exchange deal with the Soviets.
This would prove in time to have been a wise judgement......
When pilot 'Francis G Powers' (Austin Stowell) is shot-down on a spy-mission over Soviet territory and is captured
alive the exchange deal plan becomes a real prospect.
A negotiator is required, 'James B Donovan' is approached to go into East Berlin beyond the newly constructed wall
to broker a deal.
This, would not prove an easy task as it seems his negotiations are with more than one source, hearing of a student
'Fredric Pryor' who had found himself trapped in East Berlin during the construction of the wall, 'James B Donovan'
gambles that he can negotiate the release of both the American airman and the student in exchange for convicted
Spy 'Rudolf Abel'
Will his gamble come off ?

While the acting and visuals are fantastic, and Tom Hanks convincing in his lead role, the biggest fault of Bridge of Spies is the pacing. The flow of this film is cold, slow and frequently boring. The reviews describe this as a "thriller" but I failed to be thrilled. There was a moment in the film when a spy plane was shot down (with excessive CGI) that was momentarily intense, but then it was back to more of the slow, cautious dialog, with lots of drinking, drudgery and cold imagery of cold-war Germany. Another observation: the music was tepid, and it's disappointing to see Spielberg working with someone other than John Williams after all of these years.

Spoiler Alert: plot of movie revealed in this review.
I wanted to see this movie because I saw a documentary about the 13-year old newspaper boy who was given the hollow nickel coin with the microfilm in it, who turned the coin over to the police, leading to the arrest of the Soviet spy Able. This movie extended that story with the exchange of Able for 2 Americans imprisoned by the Soviets and East Germans: the U-2 pilot Gary Powers and an American student.

I am surprised that Gary Powers was portrayed as such a 'cavalier' character. Given his highly skilled, dangerous and responsible job, and how he died by sacrificing himself to save people on the ground, I would have thought Powers to be a much more serious person. I am glad the movie showed that he was vindicated, albeit too many years after his death. I could have done without the parts about Donovan's family; or about Able's purported relatives. I would have liked to have found out how Able was really treated by the Soviets, once he was returned. But I suppose I can research that for 'real' history.

I didn't think I'd like this movie because so much of it is dark and gray, and it's mostly talk with very little action. But now, the day after seeing it, I am liking it more. I hope it is historically accurate, although movies are not obliged to stick to the objective, accurate story-telling. It is very low key but still entertaining and has some historical value.

Entertaining, not too much liberal slant against expectations once I found out Tom Hanks was starring. The Russians and East Germans were clearly still the bad guys, as it was back then in Berlin; although the few scenes with women and children jumping out of the 3rd floor of buildings to either freedom, or their death did not cover half the human tragedies created by the soulless socialist/communist prison system of the East.

We are delighted that Mark Rylance received an Oscar for his performance in this film.  I may never worry again because,  "Would it help?"  His delivery of this line on several occasions was perfectly nuanced each time.  Hanks was absolutely convincing as an insurance executive who was able to argue both sides of the "one incident, more than one victim" conundrum.  His relationship with Rylance's character grew and deepened over time; their parting was especially touching.  We think Spielberg hit another one out of the park with this movie that doesn't seem to have received as much attention as it deserved.

First question bout this movie is "why?"  We all know that the Russian and East Germans were the bad guys and that everything we do is justified by our endless search for peace, freedom, and democracy.  We also know that the pain man inflicts on other men is boundless.  We know how rabid the masses become when infected with nationalism/jingoism and how easily a few sociopathic leaders can inflame gullible. Most of us are aware of the danger mobs offer and that hateful men/women will shoot people's houses if they disagree with peaceful people who live in that house.  We shoot abortion facilities don't we?  In sum, this movie simply reprises that which reality and history has taught us (except we did not pay attention) a thousand times...that human nature is not a pretty thing.  Do we need a semi-fictional or even a non-fictional second look at human depravity? Nope.

Fascinating study of the manner in which personal integrity can advance patriotic aims.  In my estimation, BRIDGE OF SPIES is Hanks' best performance wedded to Spielberg's best film.  As in MUNICH, Spielberg skewers spying as organized savagery--too simplistic an evaluation of the secret warfare that is crucial to national security.  Mark Rylance and Amy Donovan deserve better scripts; Russian spies and American housewives are surely more voluble in any era than the film's writers apparently can imagine.  Middle-class daily life in the early 1960's is reconstructed impressively right down to the kids' TV dinners served on the family's living-room coffee table.  Spielberg even managed to avoid a habit that has diminished some of his best work--attachment of a lengthy denouement to an otherwise spellbinding story; Spielberg gets in and out of BRIDGE OF SPIES adroitly, leaving his audience with plenty to think about.

Very good movie.  Being a boomer and growing up at about his sons age in the film I remember the fears and the world of that time. I appreciate the films part narrative on how loose some of the legal and Gov't people played with the law.  If some find it offensive understand that we see the same jingoistic attitudes in dealing with the war on terror so many decades later.  Donovan (Hanks) gets to remind us that Americans are not  American because of race, ethnic group or faith but are part the most successful experiment in representative democratic government because we believe in it. Today we still find it difficult to balance the safety of our homes with the protection of our rights.  The films tense mood and stark landscapes echo the bleakness of a still post-war Europe and ever present fear of Soviet plans for world domination.

Very well done but I never felt it was the fifties or more than a story "based on" actual events.  From the first scene, I'm pretty sure the subway cars still had incandescent bulbs and those hand holding straps for passengers.  Whatever.  There is some commentary on the disc that the people who worked on this movie knew about Gary Powers but not the swap, which like the joke about World War II, was in all the papers.

My recollection of the duck and cover stuff is that we never actually did any of that.  Yes, there were Civil Defense signs everywhere but we never had a rehearsal or filled our bathtubs to conserve water.  I also recall that Gary Powers was vilified upon his return, where the movie suggests a brave man whose return was met with a mild distaste.

The story about the student in East Berlin was new to me.  He's interviewed in the short that accompanies the movie and assuming the movie tells this accurately, it seems like he still doesn't realize how lucky he was.  The short also features Gary Powers' son who tells a very different story about his father which, for all I know, might be the truth.

Fact or fiction, it was well done but stretched out.  There's a scene near the end where Tom Hanks is standing alone on the bridge, his job completed.  This is obviously the end of the movie but it goes on from there.  There is a wonderful moment with kids climbing a fence but this could have gone earlier and saved some time.

Steven Spielberg, director of Bridge of Spies, written by Matt Charman and Ethan and Joel Cohen, reenacts the events leading to the exchange of Rudolf Ivanovich Abel, a Soviet spy convicted of espionage by the American government, for U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers (shot down in Soviet airspace), and an American economics student, Frederic Pryor, on February 10, 1962.  Tom Hanks brings his customary gravitas, humor, and integrity to the role of James B. Donovan, formerly General Counsel for the Office of Strategic Services (OSS), and in the film, an insurance lawyer.  In a nice cameo, Jims boss, played by Alan Alda, urges his employee to defend Abel, since the United States has to appear to be giving Abel a fair shake in the eyes of the world.  However, Abels conviction is a foregone conclusion in the eyes of everyone but Donovan.

When Jim meets Abel in 1957, the lawyer is taken with this soft-spoken and self-contained man who will not sell out his country.  Instead of mounting a perfunctory defense, Donovan does everything that he can to exonerate Abel, and later argues his case all the way to the Supreme Court.  The second half of Bridge of Spies is a dramatic portrayal of Donovans efforts to make a deal with the East Germans (Pryor is their prisoner) and the Soviets.  If Donovan succeeds, Abel will be repatriated to Russia and Powers and Pryor will return to the United States.  There are formidable obstacles in Donovans path, not the least of which is the CIA: American intelligence officials do not care about Pryor, but Donovan wants both young men to go home.

This is an earnest and engrossing movie based on historical events.  If you want to learn about the films many inaccuracies and anachronisms, check out the Internet Movie Database for goofs, of which there are many. In addition, Spielberg cannot resist sensationalizing the Cold War paranoia that gripped both sides during the fifties and sixties.  We see stern-faced teachers prepping their terrified students for Armageddon; angry neighbors and strangers hissing at and attacking Donovan for defending Abel; and Donovans stay-at-home wife, Mary, played by Amy Ryan, imploring him to back off for the sake of his family. Both Hanks and Rylance are outstanding in their respective roles, and the final portion of the film is riveting.  Hanks flies to Europe where he feels as if he has entered the looking glass into Wonderland.  Trying to get a straight answer from anyone seems impossible, but Donovan is a savvy negotiator who delivers persuasive arguments.  The cinematography is dark, moody, and atmospheric, and Bridge of Spies transports us to a time when America had one major enemy--the USSR--and was willing to do anything to neutralize the Soviet threat.

Bridge of Spies is easily the best film I have watched in a long time. The acting is brilliant, Tom Hanks should have got an Oscar,  Mark Rylance deservedly won best supporting actor as Rudolf Abel. He doesn't have that much screen time, but for the film to work so well, it is essential that the audience has sympathy for Abel and Rylance does a great job of developing the character so that we feel that sympathy by the time the exchange is finally made. I loved the scene where the FBI are searching his apartment and he calmly palms the crucial code message and covers it with paint.

The locations were well done as well. Berlin looked and felt like it must have done in the early 1960's I liked the sub-plot about Charles Pryor too, where Donovan knows full well that the Russians pulled the strings in East Germany and the East Germans just did as they were told. He knew that including Pryor in the exchange was a done deal despite all the huffing and puffing of the Germans.

To conclude, bravo to all concerned, I wish we had more films of this quality to watch.

I just watched Bridge of Spies for the third time. I found the acting in this intriguing drama to be some of the best in my lifetime. The time period of the cold war between Germany, Russia and the United States is extreme in the intrigues of spies, threats of nuclear war and a fractured Germany. Dangerous missions by unsung heroes and unknown players quietly serving their nation is the basis of this movie. Tom Hanks does an excellent job making us feel and uderstand the actions of this spy .A movie that deserved an Oscar. I will watch again.

This movie needed 20 minutes cut from it.  Only Spielberg would be able to meander the way this movie did in the third act.  Points down for the only women in the movie being a "wife" and "secretary" who had NOTHING important to say.  They could have been cut completely and nothing would be lost.  Rylance was FANTASTIC.  Best actor in the film.

Typical of Spielberg movies, there were a few real characters but most caricatures. Its hard to take the emotions of the "real" characters seriously when there are so many obvious phonies.  I must be the only person that feels like this about Spielberg  movies but I wouldn't have watched the movie had I known.  The audience is not smart enough to figure out who the bad guys are so we are presented with cartoon bad guys.  Example--the fake family of the Russian spy shown to Hanks to appeal to him emotionally.  These people were so obviously a plant that the audience feels satisfied that we American are so much smarter than our Russian counterparts that we are able to unmask the deception.  How about some nuance instead.  Give the Russians  and the audience some credit for having a little bit of intelligence.  I would have liked to come away from that scene thinking, " I wonder if that family was real or a plant" .  Or, " should I feel sorry for this Russian spy's family or not, maybe they are a plant:"  Instead I am bludgeoned by intentionally extra clumsy acting so I don't miss that the Russian are trying to manipulate Hanks.  OK, I know that is way to much but I had to get it off my chest.

Forget the Hollywood acting.  Rylance is most probably the best British actor alive today.  As a result of these two, the movie became a remarkable, masterful telling of the true life story of Rudolph Abel, Russian spy, and James Donovan, attorney, and a spy exchange that became a centerpiece of the drama of the Cold War.  I highly recommend this movie.

Spielberg is one of the greatest director's in film history. He made his name directing brilliant popular films for the general audience, often accompanied by the disdain of elitist critics.

Which makes what follows a bit ironic. Because when Spielberg begins to delve into politics, even in passing, the populism of his early career evaporates into a smug disdain for the same audience he once made films for. Not sure where it began, but his later films have been a strange combination of moral vapidness, moral equivalence, and a studied, self-aggrandizing contempt for the common man. In Saving Private Ryan you had the bizarre line about how saving Ryan would perhaps be the only decent thing they did in WW2, with the nobility of the enterprise of putting down Hitler and liberating Europe an afterthought. In Munich it was the alleged moral equivalency between terrorists and those who fight them. In Lincoln it was the myth of the great, enlightened leader dragging the ignorant, fearful masses into the light.

While Bridge of Spies shares the tendencies of the others (such as creating a false equivalency between Soviet espionage and US attempts to combat Soviet aggression; made all the stranger by the film's depictions of the building of the Berlin Wall) it is Lincoln with which it shares it biggest faults. In Lincoln Spielberg propounded the myth that Lincoln single handedly pushed through the 13th Amendment against a bigoted Northern populace. Except the 13th Amendment  passed the House with 7 votes more than the required 2/3rds majority and was subsequently ratified by the requisite number of states. Spielberg went so far as to exaggerate opposition to the amendment, which served to build the theme of a man of principle heroically standing against the ignorant mob.

In Bridge Hanks is the man of principle and we are the ignorant rabble he is standing righteously against. The film deliberately depicts the accused Soviet spy Abel as a quiet, sensitive man who may not be guilty and anyway was just being a good soldier. In fact Abel was guilty as hell and likely ran the Soviet US espionage operation, starting during Stalin's regime. But allowing this undercuts the heroic tale. And worse we are depicted as loathsome. Not only have we (the film suggests) been unfair to Abel and Hank's character in representing him, but we are allegedly driven by irrational fear of nuclear war (seriously) which the film depicts as childish despite being set only a few years before the Cuban Missile Crisis.

The apex of this tale of righteous man of principle standing up to the ignorant, bigoted masses is a completely fictional scene where someone pours gunfire into Hank's house while his family cowers in terror. Spielberg would not even go with the standard brick through the window route. Nope. Having persecuted Abel and Hanks, having been driven by unfounded fears which seem all too founded even within the film's universe, we stoop so low that we will even engage in cold blooded murder.

Other distortions and exaggeration follow, enhancing Hank's heroic status, but those are standard cinematic license. But to me the dripping contempt for the common man (you and me) in which Spielberg's frames the story ruins the experience. It has its moments and Spielberg has an admirable economy as a filmmaker. But seeing a brilliant populist director bogged down in elitist self-pandering is unfortunate.

I was accused last night of being someone who doesn't like dramas after watching this movie and complaining about it. I wasn't the only one complaining though - 2 of our group loved the movie and 2 of us were feeling lucky to have made it through the whole thing without falling asleep. I like dramas, I just expect some actual drama in my dramas - enough to keep me interested. What did keep me interested was the acting, the scenery, and the possibility of an interesting plot-line. But what was really annoying were the long, drawn out scenes paired with music building to loud crescendos telling me that I should be experiencing some kind of intense drama at these spots, but... not really feeling it. It actually reminded me of the movie The Monument Men which similarly should have trimmed down some scenes and not been so full of itself with the pregnant pauses and commanding music - and you just feel the movie's embarrassment as you think - oh - I don't think they quite got where they wanted to go.

This wonderful and I think underrated film by Steven Spielberg is a joy for people who like thoughtful movies, as opposed to "shoot-em-ups."  What's especially interesting was the beauty of the filming, a huge contrast to spy films from the 1960s which were often very dark.  Every shot is beautiful, some might say "gorgeous," and a reflection of the director at his peak and terrific cinematographer.

The plot involves the Cold War, our relations with Russia and Germany at that time following WWII, and in part, an episode many Baby Boomers will remember at least vaguely concerning Francis Gary Powers and a spy plane that was shot down in Europe.  Fascinating and fun.

Won a best supporting actor award at the Oscars recently, well deserved.  Lead actor Tom Hanks was a joy in every moment onscreen, even moreso than usual, we thought.  A pleasure to see, both in the theater, and later, on BluRay purchased here on amazon.  Much to enjoy here.

This movie is about a spy exchange between the US and the Soviet Union during the Cold War period of the late 1950s, with an additional complication involving East Germany.  It is often difficult to make a movie interesting when everyone already knows the outcome.  Despite that, I did enjoy this movie because the acting was quite good and the movie was fast-paced.  I thought Tom Hanks was excellent.  Mark Rylance (the Cromwell character in Wolf Hall) played the Russian spy, a role for which he won this year's Oscar for best supporting actor.  His role was surprisingly subdued, but effective.  His expressions and tones of voice rarely changed.  He played a man who was reticent and seemed resigned to his fate.

I gave this movie 4 stars instead of 5, because I don't think it qualified to be an outstanding movie.  I thought it was very good and I would recommend it to those who might be interested in this type of movie.  I'm glad I watched it.

The movie kept my interest even though I was familiar with the events portrayed. While the movie took a few liberties with the facts for dramatic effect, it did reveal some of the behind the scenes negotiations that were not reported by the media.

Quite frankly rather disappointing.  A great story, without a doubt, but I felt the movie lacked the drama and tension I was expecting in a high stakes thriller.  I don't fault Hanks much (Ever seen 'Castaway'?  The guy is BRILLIANT!) but instead think how the story was told or laid out was the reason.  Pacing was slow and disjointed at times.  The movie showed hardly anything of the difficulties endured by Francis Gary Powers (which would have then better showed the tension involved in the prisoner exchange), the Russian spy was portrayed as a total gentleman and class act (unsure if that is historically accurate or not), the flying related scenes of the American U-2 pilots receiving TOP SECRET/classified instruction about the spy plane were pathetic (class in an OPEN hangar? really?), hardly any emotion by the fellow U-2 pilot who was sent to ID Powers during the prisoner exchange, the prisoner negotiations before the exchange sounded like casual business meetings.  Not a total waste of 2 hours but whereas before watching the movie I was seriously considering buying a copy because, hey, it's Tom Hanks!  But after seeing it, no way.

I enjoyed it, even as I know the Cold War was insidiously manufactured by certain corporate and state capitalist elites to be a vicious imposition on the public. We're relentlessly manipulated by our elites. In one scene, the hero's young son has filled the bathtub explaining to his father that, when The Bomb strikes, they'll be needing a ready supply of water. The boy and his classmates, terrorized by propaganda films of atom bomb blasts to which they're subjected in public school, learn how to "duck and cover"  Allen Dulles is portrayed in Bridge as a benign authority. (In reality, he was an evil man, "the shark"as his wife and mistress referred to him.) Tom Hanks portrays an upper crust insurance lawyer, a good and courageous man who feels duty bound to serve his country. He respects his client, the Soviet spy. It was a mutual respect, and that may have been actual.

When one hears the phrase, "a Steven Spielberg film", a number of near Pavlovian reactions occur.  Some good, some not so good.  Powerful; sentimental; schmaltzy; predictable.  WAIT.  The last one just doesn't cut it anymore, especially with "Bridge of Spies".  This Cold War elegant painting of a movie is simply a fine piece of work from a powerful craftsman.  What appears from the promotional poster to be yet another Tom Hanks-is-the-good-smiling-American-hero-boring-us-again movie, is in fact, anything but.  This may be the best work Hanks has done in quite some time, certainly since he entered his elder statesman phase.  He encompasses the role of James Donovan, a comfortable, Brooklyn based insurance lawyer in the early 60s with cardigan wearing ease, and imbues the character with a particularly old school American cinema veritas that is all the more surprising in its effectiveness, as the viewer expects the predictable Hanks/Spielberg schmaltz to turn around the next frame's corner, yet never does.  A clear signpost ahead (to paraphrase the late, great Rod Sterling) of a quality film is the harmony of its casting.  The always emotionally intelligent Amy Ryan is pinpoint as ever as Donovan's sort of long suffering wife, and Mark Rylance as the Russian spy Rudolph Abel earned his Best Supporting Actor nomination with a beautifully understated dignified gem of a performance.  The subtly intelligent script by the Coen brothers (yes, them) both reminds us of the dark edginess of the Cold War in all its nuclear showdown possibilities, while cleverly presenting a view of the "enemy" as suffering humans too.  With production design and cinematography both of Seth Curry like accuracy, the viewer is fully transformed into the darkly difficult Eastern Europe of the early cold war era.  Guided by pitch perfect performances every step of the way---Sebastian Koch the wonderful lead in "The Lives of Others", Mikhail Gorevoy, Jesse Plemmons (try not to think of his well deserved demise in "Breaking Bad") Dakin Matthews and the always crackling Alan Alda---the intertwined stories of Gary Powers and Abel come to life in a manner and with mannerisms that both detail this period in history and cry out for a little bit of our better angels today.
Well worth seeing, and maturely provocative, "Bridge of Spies" is a walk to be taken.

Great film with the combined talents of Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg, The acting was top notch, photography superb and the characters well developed. I remember thinking that the film was totally believable while watching it and suddenly realized that the events depicted in the film really happened.
The most sympathetic character in the film was the Soviet spy which I found somewhat surprising. Hanks was the spy's attorney and they developed a deep mutual respect by the film's end.
All in all, an enjoyable film which seems to perfectly capture the essence of the Cold War rivalry with the former Soviet Union and the intense feelings of protectionism it engendered in our government. Plus - it's just a damn good story!

Actor Tom Hanks and Director Steven Spielberg once again teams up to make a historical Cold War drama thriller about an American lawyer who was asked to negotiate the release of an American spy whose U-S plane was shot down in the Soviet Union. The result of the tandem's 6th partnership is Bridge Of Spies.

James B. Donovan is an insurance lawyer who was asked to defend an accused spy Rudolf Abel,who was caught in some illegal activities in the United States. The prosecutors were thinking that he will not take the case seriously amidst the Cold War. But apparently he did. Despite of being proved guilty,he avoided the death penalty for his client. Also,Donovan tried his best to defend Abel up to appealing his case in the Supreme Court.

Years after,Donovan was asked to negotiate for the release of Francis Gary Powers,an American spy was caught in the USSR after the U2 pilot plane was shot down. They did this through an exchange of spies with the United States releasing Abel and the Soviets releasing Powers. Aside from that,Donovan also worked for the release of Frederic Pryor,an American economics graduate student,who was visiting his German girlfriend in East Berlin.

The film was interesting. No question about it. While the film had an understated impact,the unpredictability of the characters kept the movie interesting from beginning to end. It was nice to see a something wherein friendship is developed among people who wouldn't trust each other. As for the performances,Tom Hanks could be considered superb. But Mark Rylance definitely deserves an Academy Award nomination for being great as the Soviet spy Abel. As for Spielberg,he still remains the best director when it comes using visual images in telling the story. This deserves the highest rating.

GREAT MOVIE!  Tom Hanks delivers stellar performance and why wasn't he nominated for an Oscar??  Fascinating story (based on true events).  As usual, he becomes the character he is portraying and you are right there as everything takes place.  THUMBS UP!!

I was blown away by this film.  It could have focused on the basic suspense--on what will happen next.  Instead it focused on the ethical issues involved.  The suspense in these far outweighed the mere question of who will live or who will die.  It isn't preachy.  It isn't beating you with a stick.  It is telling a story that is worth hearing and worth reflecting on.  If you want to watch a thoughtful thriller, this is the one for you.  The questions grappled with in this film are not strange, abstract philosophical theories (which, in movies, are also often off the wall, like the Matrix trilogy).  This deals with questions which are everyday, especially--fear vs. the human rights of the one you fear.  Quite the question to bring up in these decades of terrorism.  The film doesn't lean one way and then the other, like some movies.  Those claim to leave the viewer with the ability to decide the answer on their own.  They don't.  All they do is leave the viewer with a question as confused and sticky as it was before they watched said movie.  This movie takes a character who is firm and who believes in something enough to risk his life for it.  It places this character in a situation in which every facet of that belief will be challenged.  It shows his response.  You, the viewer can decide whether he is right or wrong.  The movie, and history, have their answer, but the film is not preachy.  It opens up discussion.  Oh, and it is thrilling, filled with interesting--and often likable--characters, and well-made.  It's a good movie plus all that wonderfulness.  Go watch it, if you haven't already.  It is well worth the time!  Have a discussion afterwards too!

I must also add that, for a historical spy movie, it did not seem like it was much exaggerated.  I know nothing of the original events; but, let's face it, we can tell when the movie director is obviously exaggerating.  I don't think it was the case here.

I have never taken a liking to (and admittedly, am quite terrible at), U.S. and World History, unless they are presented to me in a realistic, interesting manner.  However, I do enjoy good historic thrillers (especially when they are "based on true events," such as "Monuments Men," "Saving Private Ryan," "Band of Brothers" and "Pacific," "The Imitation Game" and now, "Bridge of Spies."  Mr. Spielberg and his company (including all actors), captivated and held my interest througout the movie, especially from the incredibly realistic beginning to the end of the movie, a rare accomplishment, but one I would gladly see again simply because it is that good.  And, just because I "have never taken a liking to" a particular subject does not mean I do not wish to increase my knowledge regarding it, rather, quite the opposite, and all of the movies mentioned above (along with many others), have done exactly that for me - enjoying learning more.  I would highly recommend this movie (and the others mentioned above), to anyone who likes or doesn't like history.  Tom Hanks is superb, as is this movie, and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes or doesn't like history.  The notes, comments and special features at the end of the movie are fascinating as well.

I didn't get to see this movie in the theater, and I only buy movies on DVD if I'm pretty sure I'll want to watch it more than once.  This movie is even better than I'd hoped!  Five stars!  I affirm everything the other 5-star reviews say.  Superb storytelling, superb acting, an excellent history lesson about this particular time in history (I was only a toddler during the time in which this movie is set).  It has relatively little "action" in terms of chases, fight scenes, etc., but it is deeply emotionally engaging and often both tense and intense (I was seriously biting my nails for various characters in some scenes).  It is also very thought-provoking from beginning to end (and after the end, when I and the people who had watched it with me launched into literally hours of discussion).

I was constantly thinking that I thought Donovan (Tom Hanks) was right about most of his decisions, wrong about a few, but I always liked him because in every decision he was highly principled and certainly brave and heroic, and most of the time I agreed with him (1000% after he agreed to negotiate the prisoner swap with the Soviets and East Germans -- he was at his most heroic then).  The kind of man I'd want as a close friend for life, and debates/discussions with him would have been epic and fascinating.  Donovan seemed so ordinary on the surface, but scratch the surface and you discovered a man of rare intelligence, human insight, moral and ethical principle, cleverness, and courage.

The movie deeply engaged my emotions and really made me think.  I cared very much indeed for Donovan and both American men he struggled to save.  I even cared about Mr. Abel, the enemy spy he had to defend at trial.  This movie isn't relevant only in a historical context.  The emotional, moral, ethical, and political questions raised in this movie are forever relevant, especially in our modern times.  I and many of my family and friends will re-watch this movie many times.

This movie was suspenseful, and very emotional & entertaining. Based on a true story, it was interesting to see them include building the wall between east and west Berlin. Rudolf Abel was brilliantly played as well.  Tom Hanks who played James Donovan actually believed that Abel deserved a fair trial, which ended with Abel being given 30yrs in prison instead of a death sentence. The judge was clearly bias as most Americans were at that time in history. I'm sure the hatred for Donovan was palatable and frightening for his family. In the end, Abel was used by the gov't to swap a downed pilot, but Donovan also included a deal for am American student. At that time the FBI didn't think it was a wise decision to include anyone else but the pilot. I loved the ending of the movie, which was bitter sweet for Donovan. (no spoiler alert needed) Many of us lived through the Cold War and were fortunate enough to have experienced the wall that divided East from the West taken down. What an awesome moment of history, thanks to Ronald Regan. Great movie!

The telling of this story is thorough and it moves along well.  Highlighting the difficulties of people dealing with each other under circumstances beyond their making while maintaining dignity, respect and integrity is very well performed by Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance, as the Russian spy.  Directed masterfully, it demonstrates that serious business can be conducted professionally, even covertly, with recognition we have roles we play.  Playing our roles, keeping our word:  Trust.  Old concepts with reliability, dependability and accountability that make things work.  Not very apparent these days.  Neither is the wisdom of thinking ahead, anticipating the way things will need to work to get the best outcome for everyone.  Heavy duty stuff.  Will it make a difference?

Bridge of Spies, directed by Steven Spielberg, is a nominee for Best Picture for the 2016 Oscars. The film also received 5 other nominations, including Actor in a Supporting Role, Original Score, Production Design, Sound Mixing, and Original Screenplay and for good reason. Tom Hanks is as always, wonderful. They year is Cold War era 1957,and Hanks plays a New York insurance lawyer named James Donovan. Donovan is selected to provide defense, pro-bono for a man named Rudolf Abel, an artist but also a man that the United States has accused of spying for the Russians.
Donovan makes many enemies as he upholds the law in Abel's defense and while everyone wants him "to hang" (to get the death penalty), Donovan is focused on the law and due process. He also has the ability to foresee the future at a time when maybe an American may be held by Russia - keeping Abel alive to be able to trade for an American if need be. A master negotiator, Donovan takes the offer by the CIA to travel to East Berlin and conducts several negotiations with the Soviets and East Germans to exchange Abel for a recently captured U.S. Air Force pilot, Francis Gary Powers and a Yale economics student. This is a story about maintaining ones integrity, justice and the American way of life despite the herd or pack mentality or hysteria to send "the enemy" to the death. A brilliant film, a superb cast and wonderful performances all around.

The anti-hero of Bridge of Spies is a washed up former Russian brigadier general living in Brooklyn (Is there ever any end to Brooklyn?) who is arrested on espionage charges. He is much more interested in his hobby of acrylic painting than in the occasional decryption of intelligence messages for the Soviets. And it is deep into his art that we find him when the film opens. Mark Rylance as the general plays a deeply stoic figure against the principled activism of his defense attorney, Tom Hanks, the all-American who believes in the rule of law and public service to right a wrong. Hanks becomes the crusader for the man who has lost his faith in the certainties of ideology. Rylance's stoic refrain at several setbacks in the plot comes as a counterpoint to Hanks emotional outrage and engagement. His reply is always: "Would it matter?"

I am a cold war era fan, an avid Tom Clancy genre reader. This movie is a very credible effort to portray not only a real conflict but one of the only real spy exchanges ever done with the rulers of the iron curtain. The Soviets NEVER wanted to trade prisoners because they felt that it made them look a mix of weak politically and that it just did not look TOUGH. And what was a Russian who did not look TOUGH worth? Pretty much nothing.

So Tom Hanks yet again is portraying an American guy who is trying to do not just the easy thing but the right thing in a world really gone astray wayyyy off the railroad tracks that most of us consider modern day life. Its easy to be a gun wielding psychopath, a cut out character who just is there to look tough and tote a gun.
What makes this a real epic story is how his character pulls the hidden levers of government even when those governments by any standard of today are rip-off-artists of the highest caliber shysters and one step above third world banana republic dictators.

Another great Spielberg/Hanks movie !!!  Hanks is superb as a New York  insurance lawyer, fourteen years beyond his past as a Prosecutor seeking justice at the Nuremberg Trials, is suddenly dropped into the world of Spies to provide a credible legal defense for accused Russian spy, Rudolph Abel.  After Abel is tried and convicted, he returns to his law firm in NewYork, only to be brought in to seeking to trade his client, Abel, for captive U-2 pilot, Gary Francis Powers.  Armed only with his U.S. Passport and a dry, quick wit, he crosses into East Berlin, to negotiate Powers' release with East German and Russian covert representatives . . .  An excellent movie, only marred by U-2 shoot-down imagery that doesn't have the tail-section ripped off by explosive shockwaves from three or more Soviet Surface to Air SA-2 Guideline missiles;  plus the U-2 imagery used, was not portraying the U-2B actually flown by Powers, but rather a twenty years newer TR-1 version of the U-2 design.  So much for accurracy in an age of Cinematic realism . . .

you know it's good.  This movie is "inspired by actual events" meaning it's a movie, okay, not a documentary.  It starts out in 1960 and is made the way movies were then, meaning no big car chase scenes or highly improbable shootouts with the bad guys.  It has a real script with excellent acting from Hanks down to the extras in the background.  Hanks plays an insurance attorney that is a partner in a large law firm in Brooklyn.  He is assigned the case of a man accused of being a Russian spy.  The government wants the spy to get a fair trial before they hang him and everybody but Hanks, a big believer in the Constitution, is all for it.  If you were old enough to know what was going on between the USA and the USSR in those days, and I was, then you already know how the story ends but there's a lot of suspense before you get there.  There's no sex, the F word is used a few times, and no blood and guts violence so the kids will lose interest fairly quickly with this movie.

As a baby boomer and child of the Cold War, the story of Francis Gary Powers was familiar to me. My early teens were filled with newspaper coverage of possible missile attacks, fallout shelters, the building of the Berlin Wall, and the Cuban Missile Crisis. We practiced air raid drills in our classrooms, and watched news coverage of the desperate Germans who died attempting to get over the Wall by any means possible. One especially memorable attempt involved a hot air ballon that crashed on the Communist side of the Wall, but the occupants made it over safely. Tom Hanks is superb, and the story evoked many memories.

I give the film 1 star because I can't give it fewer.  I love Cold War books and films.  This one is politicized garbage and historical revisionism using a modern critique provided by Obama and the DNC (I don't mean this literally, but by all appearances, it seems so).  This is Spielberg's second bomb within the last few years.  He seems hooked to the notion that we must view history through the lens of the Democratic party in the United States.  The writers overuse of tired lines and modern political cliches (i.e., Tom Hanks' exhortation that executing a Soviet spy "is not who we are" seems awfully close to the line Obama utters over and over with regard to anything that doesn't fit his political philosophy, to the extent he has one).

The treatment of the CIA in the film is absurd.  The treatment of the average "Joe" American citizen is also ridiculous.  The citizen is the mob.  The CIA incites the mob and doesn't give a damn about, well, anything except achieving whatever mission comes it's way.  In this film, only a few are enlightened enough to believe that an American student's life is worth saving from the clutches of the Stasi.  The CIA is shown to not care even a little bit about getting that kid out.  So Tom Hanks saved him and made fools of the CIA.  What a joke.  The men of the CIA at the time were not all good, but they were highly educated and many of them were very good, moral men.  Many, if not most, had served in the U.S. military.  If there was a chance they could get this kid out of a Soviet prison, they would have taken it.  In this film, the CIA operatives are portrayed as malicious dimwits.

Tom Hanks is smarmy in this film.  He just wants to "go home and go to bed."  I heard that repeatedly in this film.  There was also the line from the Soviet spy given in response to Hanks' question, "are you not worried?"  The spy responds, "would it help?"  Sort of cute when he said it...the FIRST TIME.  When they made the joke again a SECOND TIME, I gave it a pass.  Then near the end of the film, they dropped this clever little bomb a THIRD TIME.  Same question, same response - THREE TIMES.  So funny.  So clever.  Modern films are so often garbage and this one is no exception.  Please don't waste your time or money.

Hanks is perfect as a quiet, unassuming lawyer who gets roped into defending a captured Russian spy.  It is a thankless job, one no one else will take, and in spite of unrelenting opposition  from the Court, he engineers a life sentence instead of the death penalty.  This is a thrilling film, although it has a somber tone.  The scenes that occur behind the Berlin Wall are at once highly charged and thoroughly compelling.  Hanks is believable as a man capable of courageous acts will maintaining a quiet demeanor.  Anyone who remembers the urgency of these actual events will appreciate the  cliffhanger nature of sending a private citizen into East Germany to arrange for the exchange of prisoners, and Hanks' willingness to sacrifice all for the inclusion of an innocent second prisoner of the Germans is outstanding storytelling.  All in all, Tom Hanks has performed in a very demanding role that has no place for his usual good humor.  He didn't need it, because his courage and ability were enough to save the day.

Bridge of Spies is the best film I've seen from 2015.  Without giving away too much of the plot, it is about the negotiation to secure the return of Francis Gary Powers, the American pilot who was shot down while flying/spying over Soviet Russia.  I initially was not interested in the film because the trailer is drab and uninspiring.  Well, this is the rare case where the movie is actually much more compelling and gripping than the trailer.  It is the story of an unknown (at least to me) American hero.  Tom Hanks is excellent as James Donovan, the lawyer charged with making the negotiations with Soviet Russia.  But praise is also due Mark Rylance for his understated, convincing portrayal of Rudolf Abel.  This movie reminds us of why we need to be proud of our country and our constitution.  Highly, most highly, recommended.  .

The film masterfully exhibit's the atmosphere that was the 1950's and 1960's of tension,mistrust and misunderstanding during the Cold War. Tom Hanks portrays James B. Donovan in a brilliantly down-to-Earth manner of a  honest, unpretentious, tough-minded but compassionate lawyer that must navigate thru the clock and Dagger business of working with paranoid government agencies, but not working for anyone, or no-official cover.
The pleasingly unpredictable latter-career Spielberg has chosen to follow his magnificent rumination on the greatness of Lincoln with another category-resistant historical reenactment. Genre-wise, Bridge Of Spies (a reference to the Glienicke Bridge, where spy-swaps are made in shivering pre-dawn Berlin) dances between courtroom drama and espionage thriller. There is plenty of speechifying too, stirring gusts of high-minded virtue: American justice will be on trial! Its a meaty gumbo of Capra, Le Carr and Perry Mason. From Minority Report to Lincoln, another of Spielbergs enquiries into the nature of American goodness as ordained by the Constitution.

You can't go wrong with a Tom Hanks, Steven Spielberg movie.  This one was moving on a very real level.  Sit down with the family and witness a little history.  On a personal note, I was in Berlin when the wall came down.
Incredible movie,  brought me back to my childhood.  Drop and cover...how absurd....but we did it.

As usual Tom Hanks does a phenomenal acting job in this movie. I don't think there's been a movie yet that he's stared in that I didn't absolutely love (except maybe Cast Away with the volleyball-weird movie). Not to mention it's directed by Spielberg so you know it's going to be good.

Anyway, this movie is based on the true story of James Donovon, played by Hanks, a insurance lawyer who got the short straw sort of to speak, in having to defend Rudolf Adel a KGB spy living in America during the Cold War. (If you like these sort of KGB spy, Cold War movies you will definitely enjoy the series The Americans-so check that out). Many KGB spies infiltrated into America during the Cold War to relay vital information back to Russia.

Adel was outted by his own assistant and turned into the CIA and captured. Donovon was determined by moral standards to give him a fair trial despite the allegations of him being a KBG spy meanwhile forming a friendship in the end. During the same time US CIA spy Francis Powers spy plane was shot down over Russia and he was captured and sentenced to 10 years in prison (not being given a fair trial) Donovon then negotiates a trade between Adel for Powers to bring the young pilot home safely. This trade was done at Berlin's Glienicke Bridge where many Soviet spies were exchanged thus getting the nickname 'Bridge of Spies'

It's a good watch not only for entertainment purposes but for the true historical events as well. I definitely recommend it!

The setting for this based on a true story film is the 10950s  that tense period when in America children were put through classroom drills in case of an expected (or rather, feared) nuclear attack form Russia. Most people had bomb shelters stocked with supplies for the propaganda response that the Cold War ruled everyones thinking. Remember those days? If not then this film will most assuredly force you to stare at the anxiety that ruled the politics and the military and the populace during that awful time.

Steven Spielberg directs a script created by the Coen Brothers and Matt Charman and has engaged a splendid cast that offers many insights into the thinking of that period. The story (for those who are shaky on facts and dates) is as follows: In the cold war, an insurance lawyer, James B. Donovan (Tom Hanks), who hasn't practiced criminal law since he was a prosecutor at the Nuremburg trials after World War II, is recruited by the CIA and involved in an intense negotiation mission to release and exchange a CIA U-2 spy-plane pilot, Francis G. Powers (Austin Stowell) who was arrested alive after his plane was shot down by the Soviet Union during a mission- with a KGB intelligence officer, Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) who was arrested for espionage in the US. The strong anti-Communist mood at the time makes him a target from those (the general populace) who think Abel should just be executed. Abel is convicted but Donovan convinces the judge to sentence him to prison, rather than execute him, as they may at some point in the future want to swap him for an American spy the Soviets might have in custody. And of course Donovans theory works, emphasizing the humanity that can resist fear of the unknown in the time of Cold War.

The cast is uniformly excellent with special kudos to Alan Alda, Sebastian Koch, Amy Ryan and of course Hanks and Rylance. Superb script, well re-enactment of an ugly part of our history, and some fine nuances about faith in the democratic system make this one of the finest films of the year. Grady Harp, February 16

An excellent, well-acted and splendidly photographed drama. At first I began to worry that Rudolf Abel (the Russian spy) was being portrayed as a little bit too likable, thus falling into the dramatic trap of so many former Hollywood films of making the communist excessively sympathetic. This was reinforced, at first, by the crass behavior of the CIA typesalways a ready target on the silver screen.

But balance was restored when the Soviets and the East Germans were shown in equally bad light. In both cases, that cinematic illumination was probably quite realistic.

Equally realistic, and really well done, was the ambience of East Berlin. I was there on both sides in 1961just at the time this incident took placeand could marvel at how completely West Berlin had been rebuilt while WW-II destroyed buildings still pock-marked the Eastern side of the city. (In August the American Embassy warned Americans to get out of the city at once as the Russians were up to something big.) The behavior of the East German border guards was perfectly portrayedtheir special selection as photogenic, politically safe and arrogant was just as I remember it.

One neat little sight-gag was the East German machers reflexive attempt to shake hands with the American student he was setting free. Germans then ALWAYS shook hands upon meeting and leaving each other! For Spielberg to have included that little touch shows how thoroughly researched this movie was.

Perhaps the most enjoyable moment of the film for me was the look on Hanks wifes face when she suddenly learned that her husband had not been on a Scottish fishing trip but was the key element in a major diplomatic endeavor. After all the public hatred directed at the family for Hanks legal defense of Abel, which he dubiously claimed was really a defense of the best of American values, to have her realize that yes, he was right, well that little epiphany just made my day.

You can't beat a Steve Spielberg/Tom Hanks alliance but unfortunately BRIDGE OF SPIES misses the mark and so much potential. It is not bad by any means but maybe expectations are too high from this creative duo. No one can deny that BRIDGE OF SPIES tells a fascinating story of US/Soviet tensions during the height of the Cold War. The US has arrested a Soviet spy named Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance) and the Soviets have shot down a U2 spy plane and captured its pilot Francis Gary Powers. It seems like we are headed for some heavy tension and action but actually they are limited.

BRIDGE OF SPIES starts off painfully slow. It does get better so be patient. The late 50's/early 60's dress, cars and style are definitely a plus in the film. It harkens back to a frightening era of bomb shelters and the threat of nuclear war and we thought things were scary today! It was a different time and  yet somewhat relevant to today's world.
The nature of this film does make it dialogue heavy and light on action. That changes when we see the U2 pilots training and Powers' plane crashing. Also there is a fascinating piece of history as the Berlin wall goes up. A population is trapped within the walls but what is going on as the wall is being built and it might be possible to go to the other side? Now here is a fascinating but of Cold War history unlike anything else.

Hanks stars as James Donovan. He's lawyer and for some reason is chosen to be the defender of recently arrested Abel. Donovan later seems like an unlikely candidate to negotiate the exchange of spies between the US and the Soviet Union. Donovan is requested to negotiate only for Powers' release but then adds in an American student arrested in East Berlin. It's here where the story gets interesting. BRIDGE OF SPIES briefly touches over two interesting questions. The spies are being loyal to their own countries. Aren't they heroes in a sense in their own countries? Yet,  by default, that makes them enemies and traitors to the opposing nations. Also, how do a government and its citizens treat  captured spies who have been released and returned home? Are they welcomed as heroes? Did he give away state secrets? Do they have any further use to the government? In BRIDGE OF SPIES, the U2 pilots are given a fast acting poison to use in case of capture. Powers survived the crash, so did that make him a failure for living? It would have been interesting to follow the lives of both spies after the war.

Maybe it is the Donovan character, but Hanks is rather limp and emotionless through the film. It's only mildly understood why Donovan would defend Abel. The evidence is strong proving Abel is a spy and yet Donovan goes beyond trying to make sure Abel gets a fair trial and the verdict reversed. Moral questions are raised that never get addressed fully.

Mark Rylance as the Soviet Spy Rudolf Abel is the gem in this film. We've seen Rylance before but he is one of those great actors who gets lost in often small films. Finally, he has a chance to reach a broader audience as the quiet and emotionless Abel. He is fascinating to watch and hear. He creates an accent for Abel that sometimes sounds native English speaking but then is clearly not. Good job on creating a multi-dimensional character.

BRIDGE OF SPIES is somewhat disappointing but not a bad movie. It's an important part of Cold War history that is not well known. Watch the extras to learn about the real James Donovan who had a role in the Nuremberg War Trials in Germany after WW II. Donovan was later sent by the US to negotiate the release of 1113 prisoners after the failed Bay of Pigs invasion in Cuba.  At the end of negotiations, he won the release of nearly 10,000 people. Incredible man. Time for another movie about his exploits.

This was a film I put off viewing. It did not receive the acclaim most Spielberg/Hanks film receive. What a shame on my part. This was one of the most engrossing films I have seen in the past year. I have always been a fan of the Cold War spy era, and this film more than met my expectations.

It is 1957, Tom Hanks plays Jim Donovan, an insurance lawyer called by his government to defend a man named Rudolph Abel, played superbly by Mark Rylance. He was captured for the crime of espionage against the United States on behalf of the USSR.  The man is honorable, and it seems does not give away any secrets. Donovan is asked to be Abels defense attorney by his boss, played by Alan Alda. What the government wants is a semblance of a judicial process that defends anyone. Donovan, however, is not just anyone, and he goes to the wall to defend his client. The only issue the Judge in this case listens to is that Abel would be a good body to exchange if that need ever came.

As this film proceeds, we see that Donovan does not dance to anyone else's tune, he is honorable as is his client, and when the time comes when an exchange may be needed, he is the man. This is an uplifting film needed at this time in our country's history. Tom Hanks is as always a superb actor and brings life to James Donovan. However, it is Mark Rylance who plays Rudolph Abel that brings this film to the fore. An honorable spy seems like an oxymoron, particularly in light of the manner in which an exchange is processed. Such a film should be seen by all.
