Bridge of Spies (2015) is reminiscent of the 1960's and 1970's European classic spy films such as: The Spy Who Cam in from the Cold (1965), Funeral in Berlin (1966), The Quiller Memorandum (1966), Torn Curtain (1966), The Odessa File (1974), and many more.  Special praise goes for cinematography, good filming locations, and acting. Tom Hanks should be getting an Oscar nomination for the portrayal of James B. Donovan.  The film is about a lawyer who in the late 1950's gets assigned by CIA to negotiate prisoner exchange between three parties: Americans, Soviets, and East Germans.  For that reason he is sent to West Berlin (the second part of the movie)  during the times when the Berlin Wall is in the process of being raised...the lawyer (Hanks) once in West Germany finds himself embroiled in a tense negotiations, full of mind games, where one is forced to rely on his wits and intuition...

This amazingly true movie shows the importance of being true to principle, even when no one seems to be at your side, even when it goes against policy, and the movie uplifted the sanctity of the Constitution of the United States. If you don't know the outcome of this historic event, then there is suspense right to the end. It will move you to tears, and thank God that there are such men as this.

Excellent acting by the noted stars Tom Hanks (cerebral) and Mark Rykance (stoic).  History was correct with one exception.  I knew Francis Gary Powers, second-hand through his niece who I dated after his release from East Berlin. According to reports I received from his niece second hand. Powers was looked upon by the American people in total as a hero and everyone was elated that he was freed after being shot down May 1, 1960. I knew no person that held animosity towards the man for failing to kill himself prior to his capture after being shot down by Russian missiles.  The only exception that I can surmise is from the CIA which is not a barometer of the American people's thoughts and emotions in any way.  This is my only criticism of the accuracy of the accounting of the mood in the country at the time of the incident terminating Operation Accutone.  May Francis Powers rest in peace for a job well-done.

Spielberg's film craft continues to outshine all expectations.  This carefully detailed film takes the viewer on a vicarious journey back in time to a world few recall accurately.  "Duck and cover" was a social norm, not comic relief.  Everyone believed that the Soviet Union could launch a nuclear holocaust at any time.  Tom Hanks once again shows himself an excellent character actor and presents an accurate portrayal of the American family man with a duty to do what is right even when stigmatized by his neighbors.  Slight disappoint with the lack of development of the U-2 program history.  In the film, Francis G. Powers' aircraft is shot down at 70,000 feet.  Why? There ought to have been some introduction to the fact that U-2's had been flying without incident over Soviet airspace for three years prior to the shoot sown.  It was not until 1960 that the Soviets developed missiles that could reach that altitude. Only then were U-2 planes threatened.  Nevertheless, for anyone under 40, watch this film and discover what patriotism truly means, not just on the battle field, but at home in everyday life.

This is a superb Cold War thriller based upon the events leading to the exchange by the United States of Soviet spy Col. Rudolph Abel for Francis Gary Powers, the U2 pilot shot down over Russia.  Tom Hanks plays attorney James Donovan, who was instrumental in effectuating the exchange.  This film brilliantly captures the Cold War atmosphere that existed in Berlin, Germany in the early 1960s when the Berlin Wall was first constructed.  Tom Hanks, as always, is appealing and gives off an aura of integrity, which greatly adds to a film that has a taut storyline and engaging characters.  This is a fine film that viewers will enjoy more than once.  Highly recommended.  RJB.

This is an excellently done spy drama based on the true events of the cold world era.  Tom Hanks is great in the role as the lawyer who believes in his convictions.  The story is very well done and has a fantastic cat and mouse, spy versus spy plot involving the three players (Russia, East Germany and the USA) of that era.  To me, this is one of Spielbergs best films as he really does a great job at creating the old world tension during that era with scenes that realistically recreate the look of East Berlin at that time.  This is not an action packed film but instead relies on the subtle realities of the time to create a well told story with the first half of the film concentrated on the Soviet spy Abels capture (which is excellently played by Rylance) and the second half dealing with the negotiation and trade of the Russian spy with the downed American U2 pilot.  There are no big surprises in terms of the plot as this is based on real events and the story sticks to the basic events that happened but even with that this movie does a good job at creating dramatic tension throughout its 140-minute length.

This is an entertaining spy thriller that is based on real events that is entertaining and worth watching.

Bridge of Spies takes place during the Cold War in 1957 and is based on true events.  A Soviet spy has been captured and needs to be tried for his crimes.  The people are afraid of nuclear warfare and want swift and deadly justice to keep our country safe.  But who wants to defend this war criminal?  An insurance lawyer, Jim Donovan, gets the patriotic privilege of being Rudolf Abels legal counsel.

Despite his familys concerns for their reputation and safety, Jim accepts the job and represents Mr. Abel honorably.  In fact, the cards are stacked against Rudolf and some legal shortcuts were taken to get him into court.  Even when the legal discrepancies are brought forward, they are disregarded by the judge.  Jim Donovan doesnt give up and stands his ground and pleads for the court system to spare Rudolfs life as a good gesture towards Russia.

While the arraignment proceedings are taking place, a top secret U.S. pilot is shot down in Russia and a U.S. student is captured while being on the wrong side of the newly erected Berlin wall.  Jim Donovan goes above and beyond the call of duty of simply representing Rudolf Abel, and is instrumental in negotiating his safe return to his family.

Without spoiling any more details from the movie, I will say that its well worth watching for yourself. When I saw that Bridge of Spies was directed by Steven Spielberg and starred Tom Hanks, I had my expectations set pretty high.  Im happy to report that I was not disappointed and highly recommend it.  Bridge of Spies is rated PG-13 due to strong language (a few SOBs and F-bombs) and violence.  There are some emotional scenes with people losing their lives trying to reunite with loved ones on the other side of the Berlin wall.  Anyone who likes movies about war or justice should definitely check out Bridge of Spies.

More than any director in screen history Steven Spielberg breathes life into our past and makes it relevant to a contemporary audience.  In films as diverse as "Schindler's List" and "Amistad" and a few other stellar works Spielberg posits the proposition that history repeats itself and should never be forgotten.  Spielberg tackles the Cold War and he does not shy away from the complexity or enigmas inherent in the ideological war between the democratic and communist doctrines.  The Red Scare is illustrated with young schoolchildren being taught how to survive a thermonuclear war contrasted by Germans in East Berlin being walled in by their governors fearing they'll flee to freedom on the Western side.  The film is not a precise history because events are taken out of context to advance the narrative and Tom Hanks' character is an amalgam of many persons but the essence of the times is spot on.  What I found refreshing in this film is that despite the paranoia present at the time Spielberg doesn't subscribe to the notion that the West was wrong in fighting vociferously Communism  rather the Soviet Union was a despotic institution intent on expanding their grip on as many sovereign peoples as possible.  I found the end a tad sentimental but after offering strong medicine Spielberg is entitled to  his  personal flourishes.
Great story...outstanding performances.  A forgotten history America needs to know.
Although I lived through the Gary Powers incident,  there was a lot I did not know, so the movie was that much more interesting.  Of course, anything with Tom Hanks name attached is grand.
A most excellent action and suspense movie, that the whole family will enjoy.

Tom Hanks is our generation's best actor.  Stephen Spielberg is a legendary director.  That having been said, this is not a great movie.  It is too long, too slow, and too boring.  It took a moment in history of great tension and turned it into a legal procedural.  No drama, no tension.  The performances are great, but it is just dull.
It has the same problems as another Spielberg movie, "Amistad."  It loses all emotion in long speeches about the legal process.

The Good:
As expected, Tom Hanks is both witty and charming throughout the movie. Both Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance (who plays the accused Russian spy "Abel") have great on-screen chemistry. Overall, there was really good quality acting across the board. Probably one of the most lively moments occur halfway into the movie once the US military finally gets involved.

The Bad:
I think it's fair to say that the entire first half of the movie was pretty boring. You have to wait almost 45 minutes to an hour before a certain scene happens in the movie that may wake you up. Despite Hanks being portrayed as a skillful lawyer, we never really get to see any type of exciting, genius-like lawyer tactics used in the court room. The focus on the negotiations in the story are only somewhat interesting, and the suspense that it attempts to build at the end is mediocre.

Rather than shooting the movie in a dynamic way that shows the two separate stories in a parallel fashion, the movie is shot along a straight forward timeline. By showing the movie in the sequential order, it just made the movie feel longer. (2.5 hours run-time) Finally, the sense of fear and paranoia only felt mild at best. You know there's a war going on, but the real sense of urgency just isn't conveyed very well.

The Reason:

I know this is a Spielberg movie, however, unlike others, I will not simply give him a pass. The intent  and effort in this movie is definitely good. However, I just don't think that this movie lives up to the hype that Spielberg used to command. If I'm not mistaken, it's been over 13 years since Spielberg's done a major film that's appealed to average movie goers. (Minority Report 2002) This is probably the type of film that movie purists and people in the movie industry may like. I just don't see the average person really caring about this movie in the same way. I wouldn't recommend watching this in theaters. I think that if you're interested you can watch it at home and be just fine.

The Rating: 6.5/10

A copy of this title was provided for review purposes.

It seems that the lessons of history are lost on the young these days. More attention is paid to causes in history as opposed to the events that happened. When you talk about the cold war they're taught that it ended under Reagan but little about what it was or things that happened, with the exception perhaps the Bay of Pigs situation. Ask any kid who Gary Francis Powers was and chances are they won't know. Ask about the U-2 spy plane and they're likely to think its a cover band. So its nice to see the story as well as what happened around it told in BRIDGE OF SPIES.

Rather than focus directly on Powers the movie instead tells the tale from the perspective of James B. Donovan (Tom Hanks), the lawyer who was fundamental in securing Powers release. An insurance attorney, Donovan is recruited to defend Rudolf Abel (Mark Rylance), a man accused of being a Russian spy at the height of the cold war. While we know that he is guilty, Donovan takes the task assigned seriously without questioning if he is or not.

But what Donovan truly faces is a kangaroo court. No one wants this to play out honestly, especially those in charge of the proceedings. Guilt has been determined before the trial even begins and Donovan slowly comes to that understanding as requests are denied and comments are made in chambers by the judge leaving no doubt what will follow. Not only that, Donovan and his family come under attack for his taking the case, the public unaware that he was requested to do so as opposed to taking the case willingly.

With a guilty verdict in all that is left is sentencing. The crowd calls for the death penalty. Donovan reasons with the judge suggesting that we too are spying on the Russians and should one of our spies fall into their hands it might be worthwhile to have one of theirs on hand that we could offer in trade for the safe return of ours. While the case is lost, Donovan does have this at least as solace.

When he returns to work things are different. His attempt to actually be the lawyer he thought he was supposed to have altered the attitude of co-workers. But all that is left behind when the call for his services is sent out once more.

A co-existing story has unfolded as the trial was taking place, that of Gary Francis Powers and the crash of his U-2 spy plane. Pilots have been ordered to blow up their planes and if need be kill themselves rather than be taken prisoner. Circumstance have left Powers unable to do either and he is being interrogated by the Russians concerning his plane and the plans of the U.S.

These two storylines converge when Donovan is asked to help, while not actually being a representative of the government, in setting up a trade with the Russians, Abel for Powers. Shortly before this has gone on, an American student was also arrested in the now Communist controlled East Germany days after the Berlin Wall has been erected. Donovan agrees to help and although his handlers continue to tell him to forget the student he tries to set up the trade for both Americans.

The movie unravels at a slow pace but then so do the days and weeks of a trial and the maneuvering to get a deal done in the second half of the film. Slow here is not a bad thing but instead allows the story to be told. Anyone expecting guns blazing and explosions galore will be disappointed. This is the real world and how governments actually behave most of the time. It is a fascinating tale that is handled well by director Steven Spielberg. Hanks does his usual amazing job of portraying a character who is challenged by his own morals as he walks his way through a world that seems to have none.

Perhaps its a good thing that young people will have no clue who Powers was. In watching this film they may be drawn to his story as well as an in depth look at what the cold war actually was. While there is little doubt that artistic license was probably used in the portrayal of this tale the fundamentals are there and something can be learned from the film while being entertained as well. While it is extremely well made it is the story that counts and this one offers that in spades. The fact that its been nominated for best picture at this years Oscars is proof of that.

This was not an impressive movie at all. I really do not think Spielberg is that great of a director. I really don't. This was an badly written mess. It's the kind of movie that people would have loved in the 90's. A smarmy lawyer takes a case involving a spy for the Russians and fractures his relationships with colleagues over defending him like he's an innocent man. Whenever a judge or another colleague tells him not to take the case seriously, Hank's character's demeanor changes and becomes incredibly pompous, deriding the other person as an ignorant, backwards buffoon in what can only be described as extremely preachy.

Spielberg telegraphs scenes from a mile away. In one, a character is lying down on a couch, watching TV and the camera is focused on windows in the shot. It was beyond predictable that someone would immediately throw something threw the window or shoot it, and that's exactly what happened. Everything about it was so predictable and cliche, that it made it hard for me to take the rest of the movie seriously.

There was a lot about the movie that bothered me. It just wasn't good. It's not Best Picture material. It's not even TV movie material. It's incredibly shallow. Not a lot of thought was put into the production. I could see people guessing that this film was made in the 90's. There were so many other movies that could have been nominated for Best Picture instead of this one. It's as simple as that.

"Bridge Of Spies" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: During the Cold War, an American lawyer is recruited to defend an arrested Soviet spy in court, and then help the CIA facilitate an exchange of the spy for the Soviet captured American U-2 spy plane pilot, Francis Gary Powers.

The cast led by Tom Hanks (superb as usual as James Donovan) & Mark Rylance (subtle and low-key in a Oscar-nominated performance as Rudolf Abel) is brilliant. The directing by Steven Spielberg (who also produced, Oscar-nominated) is brilliant! The (Oscar-nominated) story & screenplay by Matt Charman, Ethan & Joel Coen (both Ethan & Joel wrote their fourth story or screenplay without the benefit of directing the movie themselves, the other three are "Gambit", "Crimewave" & most recently, "Unbroken") is brilliant.

The (Oscar-nominated) music by Thomas Newman (taking over for Spielberg's usual composer, John Williams) is brilliant. The cinematography by Janusz Kaminski is brilliant. The film editing by Michael Kahn is brilliant. The casting by Ellen Lewis is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) production design by Adam Stockhausen is brilliant. The art direction by Marco Bittner Rosser, Scott Dougan, Kim Jennings & Anja Muller is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) set decoration by Rena DeAngelo & Bernhard Henrich, set dressings by Billy Baker, Tara Guckeen, Michael Bruno, David L. Bush, Glenn Strauss, Mike Patterson, Vincent Fellegara, Corinne Iasilli, John Michael Kehoe, Jessica LeNoble, Maria Szynkarczuk, Juan Carlos Mendoza, Travis Wright, Florian Speidel, Helko Klunder, Jochen Schuetz, Maria Schope & Tim Zydel, set designs by Michael Fissneider & Josef Brandl is brilliant. The costume design by Kasia Walicka Maimone is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by Mark Fichera & Leo Plank is brilliant. The special effects coordinated by John McLeod, Mark Bero and Klaus Mielich & supervised by Steven Kirshoff and Gerd Nefzer is brilliant. The visual effects coordinated by Daniel Walker, Kimberly Aller, Chan Ee Jien, Sze Jia Eng, Ankit Gokani, Vanessa Seow & Alene Tan and supervised by Dinesh K. Bishnoi, Sven Martin, Charlie Noble & Sean Stranks is brilliant.

This is a brilliant, well-done and well-crafted film that is entertaining and intriguing. Tom Hanks is superb as usual (in his fourth collaboration with Steven Spielberg) as James Donovan and Mark Rylance is subtle and low-key in a well-crafted Oscar-nominated Best Supporting Actor performance as Rudolf Abel. Their supporting cast is just as superb, with Amy Ryan (as Mary Donovan) & Alan Alda (as Thomas Watters Jr.). Steven Spielberg has directed another brilliant film to his resume. This is (or was) one of the best films of the recently done fall season and also one of the best films of last year, as well, too. This is also a solid awards contender, all around, as well, too. Also nominated for an Oscar for Best Sound Mixing by Andy Nelson, Gary Rydstrom & Drew Kunin.

Great movie! During such a scary time in history they tell this tale perfectly. It has its funny parts, seriously parts, parts that pull at your heart strings, and all in all a great movie. Easy to see why it's up for best picture of the year.

Bridge of Spies is really two movies in one.  The first is about Tom Hanks playing an insurance lawyer who defends a Russian spy and who loses the case since even the judge thinks the defendant is guilty.  It's like an old-fashioned liberal message film from the 50s:  in Bridge of Spies, we learn that the U.S. legal system is not always just.  Gee, never would have guessed. About half-way through, the film transitions from the story of the convicted spy to the story of Gary Powers being shot down over the Soviet Union  while spying on it and an American grad student caught in East Germany.  The transition is set-up via some cross-cutting, but my wife and I stopped watching as the plot booged down.

Tom Hanks, Alan Alda and many more! You certainly can't go wrong with those actors. I think this is another one of Tom Hanks strong performances and probably the best one since Philadelphia. And then the story that brings you back to the reality of what life was like not so long ago. Story also reminds you about politicians policies and human nature it was going on before the Berlin Wall came down.

This one's a keeper!

First off, the acting is VERY good. The guy who plays the Russian spy is so dead pan all the time, he just cracked me up. ("Would it help?") And of course, Tom Hanks puts on his usual great performance.

Secondly, the sets and costumes really leave you feeling immersed in the time and place. Almost has you feeling like you're an eye-witness to events not a movie watcher. Well done! I LOVE a movie that can do that!

Thirdly, the plot is really great! A real spell-binder and seemed to - for all the research I can find - follow the true events pretty faithfully. Which really makes me tip my hat to the guy Hanks plays for having such guts to press the limit. To avoid it being a spoiler, that's all I'll say about that.

This is just a very well-done movie. My only criticism would be the hokeyness of the U2 pilot being tied to his disintegrating aircraft by his O2 hose. PLEASE!

I am a huge Tom Hanks fan so his name is really the only thing I need to see to want to watch a movie! However, I also love a good spy thriller so I was doubly excited to see Bridge of Spies! Add Spielberg's name to the mix and you are almost guaranteed a hit!

The movie was a bit more slow paced than I expected so it's not exactly an action flick but there's enough suspense to keep you hanging on the edge of your seat! All the back and forth trying to make a trade for spies between America and Russia was starting to drive me crazy and stress me out! I wasn't familiar with the true story it was based on so while I hoped I knew how it'd turn out, I wasn't sure.

Tom Hanks gives a stellar performance as lawyer James Donovan as I expected he would but the surprise star in this movie to me was Mark Rylance as Rudolf Abel, the alleged Russian spy. His performance was endearing and I found myself liking the supposed enemy! It's a good reminder that we are all human beings with lives and personalities regardless of where we come from or what our job is.

Bridge of Spies was suspenseful and thoughtful and while it stressed me out completely, I really enjoyed it as a whole!
Amazing. Great character driven movie about a historical event and the backstory.

Hanks and Spielberg tackle a Cold War spy-exchange against the backdrop of a freshly-constructed Berlin Wall. As one might expect from these old masters, it's expertly-crafted and loaded with gravitas; a warm, motivated take on a surprisingly under-explored chapter of recent history. It does a great job of delicately re-evaluating popular sentiment and the bullish nature of post-war international relations, too, painting heroes and victims on both sides of the dispute. The plot is very linear, though, moving on a predictable set of rails from start to finish, and that can make it feel preachy when a few of the more heavy-handed themes briefly overstay their welcome. A foundationally-strong, workmanlike offering, it's 50% desperately-uphill legal drama and 50% high stakes poker with a set of captive American souls as the ante.

"What's the next move when you don't know what the game is." James B. Donovan (Hanks) is an insurance lawyer who has been chosen to defend a Russian accused of being a spy. He manages to make the entire country, including his firm, upset with him by the time the trial is over. After a US pilot is captured the US wants to facilitate an exchange of prisoners. Once again Donovan is enlisted to help, but his plans are different than what the government wants. First thing, this is a great movie. I really enjoyed this and was entertained by it the entire time. I will say there isn't a lot of action in this and the movie really had the feel of Lincoln. To me that's not a bad thing but just a heads up. Hanks is good as usual and really brings compassion to this role. The fact that this is based on true events makes the movie that much more exciting and tense. This is a movie that I highly recommend, but again may not be for everyone. Overall, Hanks and Spielberg hit another home run. For a history buff like me this was one of the best movies of the year. I give this a B+.

Bridge Of Spies, based on the real-life incident of a US spy plane being shot down by Soviet Armed Forces during The Cold War in 1960, is a case of style over substance. Its an elegant and polished production; expect no less from Steven Spielberg; plagued by tedious storytelling. There is tension at parts, but its mostly a middling affair as those of us who slept in Political History class wonder, but don't care much one way or the other, if protagonist Rudolf Abel will be set free.

marcellee.com

Bridge of Spies  A different kind of lawyer movie, by Ira M. Pesserilo
Virtually all lawyer movies try to dramatize the courtroom by depicting dashing attorneys, like Gregory Peck (as the urbane Atticus Finch) or Joe Pesci (as the urban Vincent LaGuardia Gambini, My Cousin Vinny.) Yet, finally realism prevailed in a Big-Screen account of a famous trial. In Bridge of Spies Tom Hanks played James B. Donovan, a rather boring looking Middle Aged lawyer, specializing in insurance coverage issues with thinning hair, and a bloated belly, which he kept covered up with an expensive overcoat. He was an insurance coverage attorney circa 1957, who took a train from his upper middle class suburban home to his Wall Street Office, spending his days construing insurance policies.
One day at the office, his life would forever change. Before Gideon v. Wainright lawyers were drafted by the courts to defend individuals charged with serious crimes. James B. Donovan, over his protests, was drafted to defend Rudolph Abel, accused Communist spy, during the height of the Cold War. Once he began his representation, Donovan insisted that his client receive the full protections of the US Constitution, just like his adversaries in insurance coverage cases demanded the full protection of the insurance policies in effect. Donovan challenged the evidence, as having been seized in violation of the 4th Amendment guarantee against unreasonable searches and seizures all the way to the US Supreme Court, where he lost a 5  4 decision. For his efforts in defending his client, Donovan found himself wildly unpopular with the judge, and the prosecution who viewed his role as being a mere decal on the system, to give the appearance of fairness, regardless of the substance.
Donovan found himself universally reviled for his defense of Rudolph Abel. But this would later change dramatically. When Francis Gary Powers was shot down in the U  2 spy plane incident, James B. Donovan was called on to negotiate the exchange of Powers for Abel, which takes up the lions share of the movie.
Yet, the question remains; how can we remain true to the Constitution, when the people we are prosecuting aren't mere criminals, but agents of a foreign government who seek the destruction of our nation? This becomes especially problematic when there is no declaration of war in effect, and military tribunals cant be utilized, as in the current War on Terrorism. And on the other hand, how far can we allow our courts to deviate from our Constitution before the rights of all are compromised, and we have lost what we were protecting?
This question, asked in US v. Abel makes Bridge of Spies truly a lawyer movie for our time.

The home video BD/DVD release of the latest Spielberg film (and an Oscar nominee), will not be released until February 2nd, but  as a journalist  I was provided with an advance screener in exchange for an objective review.  I won't go into the plot very much here (no spoilers from me  and I recommend that you watch for spoilers in other reviews; after all this a suspense film) but will offer a few personal comments and then move on to the bonus material  which is some of the best Ive seen lately.

I was in high school when the Berlin Wall was built and U2 pilot Gary Francis Powers was shot down in Russia. I knew much of the story, but there were parts new to me in this film (based on the true events). I do remember the duck and cover films in school and the building of fallout shelters. If you are a baby boomer you probably remember them too.

I thought Tom Hanks acting was superb but he has such an identifiable look and voice that you cant help but seeing Tom Hanks, the actor rather than the character he plays. That, to me, is the ONLY weakness in this or any film he stars in.

There are four bonus features and they are substantial and really add a lot to the film AFTER you have seen it. The longest one  at 17 minutes  is the making of featurette with all the main cast and production crew. In addition there are comments from Gary Powers son  who founded a Cold War Museum. Next comes an eight-minute short on both the U-2 pane (they are still in operation) and the air force base where some events took of  and where parts of film were filmed. The five-minute film Spy Swap focuses on both the bridge where the final act takes place and how it was filmed and lighted. Finally is an 11-minute short on how Spielberg and his director of photography (who lived on the east side of the Berlin Wall) recreated the buildings of the period  including building a long wall for filming.

The film is 141 minutes but goes quickly. This is a period in Americas history that the younger generation will not know of unless they see this film. Like Schindlers List, Spielberg has made a historical film which can be used to teach and lead to discussion.
I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.

Steve Ramm
Anything Phonographic

1. This movie is based on the true story of lawyer Jim Donovan, who negotiated the release of US spy Francis Gary Powers in 1957.

2. It's co-written by the Coen Brothers, directed by Steven Spielberg, and stars Tom Hanks. So I expected an awesome movie. I did not get an awesome movie.

3. This happened during the Cold War, which means there is no violence or death in the movie. It's all talking. There was a great subplot about recruiting some Army soldiers into being spies, but it was dropped almost as soon as it was introduced. It was only used to set up the one action scene in the whole movie.

4. The actual spy scenes are really interesting. Too bad there were only two of them.

5. Even though it wasn't completely historically accurate, it was cool to see how the Berlin wall was being built, and how the city was reacting to it.

6. This is not a thriller. There's no real suspense in the movie. It's a drama with mostly talking, in courtrooms and back rooms. If you watch the first 30 minutes, you know what will happen during the next two hours.

7. The bridge referred to in the title is only in the movie for about 10 minutes.

8. The ending of the movie contradicts itself. It makes you think that one thing happened, but in the text at the end of the movie, it says the opposite thing happened.

9. The movie is decently written, decently acted, and well-shot. The movie is decently put together. But given the talent behind the film, I was pretty disappointed. I expected more than "decent".

One will be hard-pressed to find a more ardent defender of Steven Spielberg than yours truly. Jaws blew my mind the first time I watched it at the tender age of five. Its score, performances and stubborn refusal to showcase the shark until the end were so groundbreaking, even then my tiny brain acknowledged I was experiencing something special, something that transcended the boundaries of films I had seen before. E.T. infused my childhood with an existential wonder, which consequently led to my obsession with film.

I could go on about how I will totally overlook the sentimentality and unnecessarily drawn-out triple-ending of the otherwise incredible, deeply unsettling Artificial Intelligence, or the astonishing power and sincerity of Schindlers List (that one shot of a little red coat in the otherwise black-and-white film single-handedly  both visually and emotionally  wipes the floor with the entire Transformers quadrilogy  ironically, produced by Spielberg.) With the sole exception of Hook, which I thoroughly despise, Ill even come to the defense of Spielbergs lesser-known, not-as-well-received efforts, such as Always (a dead Richard Dreyfuss extinguishing forest fires!) and Empire of the Sun (a young Christian Bale as a prisoner of war!). The director knows film magic, and each of his films contains at least several sequences of pure awe. Remember, hes the guy who made us believe in aliens, dinosaurs, and that a man can rip another mans heart out with his bare fingers.

Spielbergs films can be grouped into two categories: those that embrace his youthful, go-for-broke spirit and boundless imagination, and those that display a mellowed, somber, very mature side of the great director. Lately, hes been dabbling with the latter: the monochrome Munich dealt with terrorism; War Horse told a classical tale of a boy and his horse; Lincoln was a painting-in-motion, depicting a crucial moment in the Presidents life So I approached Bridge of Spies with a dose of caution, worried that its solemnity may induce a yearning for the audacious, lets-do-insane-freakin-sequences of, say, Minority Report.

My fears proved mostly groundless, as I sat gripped, from start to (almost) finish of this courtroom-cum-spy drama. Yes, the director again adopts a classical style of filmmaking Frank Capra would appreciate, but its so beautifully shot by his regular cinematographer extraordinaire Janusz Kaminski (Saving Private Ryan, Catch Me If You Can), and so eloquently written by Ethan and Joel Coen (no surprise there), that the subliminally tense story propels itself along, making the almost two-and-a-half hour run-time zip by. Spielbergs gleefully audacious side is intermittently evident too, especially in the moments of literary and visual humor, peppered throughout the films narrative. Spielbergs magic is on full display, making one  for the most part  overlook the minor flaws of Bridge of Spies.

The plot, in a nutshell: After an alleged Russian spy, Rudolph Abel (Mark Rylance), gets caught in an intense, precisely-choreographed opening sequence, set in the nuclear-1950s, a seasoned insurance lawyer, James Donovan (Tom Hanks), is assigned to defend him. A parallel story-line introduces a team of drivers being trained for a stealth-like mission to take photos of potentially hostile territories; another follows a young reporter, as hes arrested (for reasons that aren't quite defined) in the tumultuous, Cold War-stricken Berlin. The film switches from courtroom drama to espionage thriller, as Donovans journey takes him to Germany, where he has to negotiate a complex, triple-prisoner exchange.

That Spielberg hooks you from the first second is a given, given the directors captivating repertoire. There are many things going for Bridge of Spies. Mark Rylance is serene and intriguing as Abel, and Tom Hanks, who can do no wrong, gives a commanding central performance that anchors the film; his eyes just keep filling with wisdom as he grows older. Spielbergs filmmaking fluency is remarkable, per usual. The cinematography smoothly morphs from strikingly beautiful imagery of a plane soaring through a blue sky, to a pirouetting, nerve-shredding crash of said plane, to dismally gorgeous shots of the Berlin Wall being built in a grey, highly hostile environment.

Most importantly, the Coen brothers script evokes philosophical musings on the meaning of patriotism; the difference between enemy and criminal, cowardice and humanityThe film resolutely doesnt take sides. The East-German, Russian and U.S. agendas get muddled, each pursuing its own intentions, and one cant help but see the parallels between the films themes and the current horrific situation in Syria. It strikes a profoundly resonant note, without ever meaning to do it.

As Spielbergs biggest defender, I have to admit his films are almost never without flaws, and Bridge of Spies is no exception. The arrested journalist subplot is under-developed, while the U.S. drivers subplot is over-cooked; neither reveal much about the characters. The film loses momentum in its second half, and becomes tonally inconsistent. Sebastian Koch (The Lives of Others) hams it up as Wolfgang Vogel, and there is a confusing car-swerving-through-icy-Berlin scene that couldve been left on the chopping room floor. The music, by Thomas Newman, is just too much sometimes  another Spielberg trope. The triple-ending syndrome strikes the director once again; the guys prone to sentimentality, and he aint backing away from it!

Gripes aside, the director masterfully guides us through an intricate and powerfully poignant story. I thought it would be overtly patriotic, but its subjectivity, sensitive performances and humor keep it this side of nationalistic. My sole real objection would be: now its time for Spielberg to remember his roots, embrace his inner child again. I hope his next film will involve anthropomorphic manifestations of dreams, or parallel dimensions, or transgender space odysseys (yes, its quite obvious that I hoped  so much  that Spielberg would direct Interstellar dammit)  or reach new frontiers that only this cinematic wizard can dare to explore.

Bridge of Spies- a fifties insurance lawyer, played by Tom Hanks, is enlisted to defend a caught Russian spy at the height of the Cold war, since we in America don't just electrocute caught spies like the Commies.  Its a thankless job no one wants. Hanks defends him well, nevertheless. Many people including the judge want to electrocute the spy. Hanks points out to the judge, as distasteful as the spy is, he didn't commit treason, he was merely working for his, the Russian government, not ours. Hanks tells the judge,"don't electrocute him, popular as that might be here in America, because we have American spies in Russia, too and we might want to swap our Russian spy for their potential  American spy at some point in the future" ...A collaborative effort from Steven Spielberg and the Cohen brothers! An authentic movie for "adults". like we used to have in old days, a real drama with real acting! A local reviewer mention that this is the type of part with gravitas that would have been played by Gregory Peck 50 years back. Like "To Kill a Mockingbird" a drama with meat...highest recommendation to date. What Cold War Russia and America were really like, extremely authentic and tense. Hanks, Best Actor. Best Movie. True story.

on my top10 for 2015

This movie is mainly factual, but not entirely "true" to the book, "Strangers on a Bridge", written by James B. Donavan.  I read Mr. Donavan's book back  in the mid '60's just after it was written.  I was in the U.S. military at the time and I developed a very strong admiration of Colonel Rudolf Able.  Colonel Able never denied being a Soviet Spy, but never divulged any information about his spy activities while in the United States.  A true Military Man, loyal to his country, (the USSR) and the secrecy of his military mission.  Colonel Able also acknowledged his gratitude to Mr. Donavon for the defense offered on his behalf after he returned to the Soviet Union.  I believe the exchange of the spies was beneficial for both the USSR and the USA.
 Mr. Donavan's book along with "Operation Overflight", by Francis Gary Powers, should be read to get a true insight to the treatment of both "Spies" by their respective capturers.

I was disappointed in this film. It was just fine. I just felt it was like so many of Tom Hanks' other movies. Good guys goes against the odds to do the right thing. Strong production values and good acting.

I was born shortly before the Cold War ended, so I cannot imagine the fear and paranoia that people went through knowing that a nuclear doomsday could happen anytime.  My parents told me about the air raid drills at school and the fallout shelters that people bought just in case Russia pressed the button.  In my opinion, the threat of a war between the USA and the USSR was for more terrifying than terrorism is today.  That terror is captured perfectly in this film by Steven Spielberg about a single exchange of a suspected Russian spy and two Americans held behind enemy lines.

The film opens when a man is apprehended in America and charged with espionage.  Nobody wants to defend this guy since his defender would be seen as an absolute traitor themselves.  Lawyer James Donovan, played effortlessly by Tom Hanks, becomes the Russian's defender and must deal with extreme indifference by the American public and even threats to his and his family's lives.  Meanwhile, in Russia, an American pilot is shot down and taken into custody.  Unlike the Russian spy, who is treated well in the US, the pilot Francis Gary Powers is locked up in a brutal prison.  Eventually, must to the disgust of some of the American public, it is decided that Powers can be traded for the spy.  The plot thickens, however, when an American college student finds himself on the wrong side of the newly constructed Berlin wall.  He too is arrested, and now there is double jeopardy as Donovan must figure out if he can free both Powers and the student or if he can only free one (and if so, which one).

The film perfectly illustrates the sort of status quo that was an important element of the cold war.  It does this by focusing on one event that seems small but was actually monumental in the eventual resolution of the conflict.  By resolving the event, the USA and USSR established a sort of trust.  A trust that I'd like to think kept the world from entering World War III for decades.  Whether the trust started with the events depicted in Bridge Of Spies or whether it existed before is debatable, but it was there.  Without trust, the human race cannot function, and there would be no order or progress.  Spielberg's film, like many of his films, shows how people, despite their extreme differences can trust each other in order to advert disaster and establish order.

Aside from the main theme of the plot, I just think the film is a perfect snapshot of the cold war.  The scene of school children viewing footage of nuclear blasts will be familiar to older viewers of the film; many of them remember the conflict very well.  Also the scenes of the construction of the Berlin wall are downright haunting.  Imagine one day being free and the next you're a prisoner in a communist country.  Nightmares like that were very real for millions in those days.  It should be noted that the contrast between sunny America and the bleakness of snowy Berlin illustrates the contrast between free capitalist nations and the horrors of communist ones.  This reinforces the differences in the two sides and why the trust built between them is so remarkable.

After the pointless War Of The Worlds remake and the lackluster Indian Jones sequel "Kingdom Of The Crystal Skull", I thought Steven Spielberg had lost it all together.  But he has clearly regained his touch with Bridge Of Spies, and I understand it when critics say this is his best since Saving Private Ryan.  I don't see too many films at the theaters these days but this is one that I really enjoyed
